TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his statement to the Parliament on 31 March this year which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if we cannot make 4 per cent growth a year, the whole lot of us ought to give it away.

I ask the Prime Minister: if the Budget tonight forecasts growth of less than 4 per cent, will he be a man of his word and give the game away? After 10 years of getting it wrong, why should anyone believe anything he predicts tonight?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Members on my left will cease interjecting.

—I made that claim, which I repeat, in contrast to the sort of view of the Opposition that growth does not matter and that what one should do is keep a pool of unemployment to keep wages restrained and inflation low. They are the miserable policies of those opposite. They do not believe that the Australian economy should grow at 4 per cent or be able to grow at 4 per cent. After nearly 30 years in office, we were growing at 4 per cent and the demand spilled into imports; that is, you were able to build so little spare capacity into the economy that after 4 per cent growth it all rushed to imports. You should just hang your heads in shame because after 30 years here, while all the economies around us were growing at sixes and eights and nines, the best we could do in Australia before it spilled into imports was 4 per cent under the hopeless, dumb policies of the present Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I repeat the claim that if Australian economic policy is such that we aim at 2 to 3 per cent growth in the economy or less—if we aim for those sorts of policies over the medium term—if we do not believe that we can go back to 4 per cent plus rates of growth so that we can have the rates of employment growth that actually bring unemployment down, then what is the point of the kinds of economic prescriptions in which Australia will have trafficked in recent years, indeed in the last 20 years?

What we are seeing at the moment is the economy coming into recovery.We have seen the economy grow by 1.6 per cent over the course of the last 12 months. This is why the doomsayers of the Opposition were saying it was still negative, in recession and contracting. Of course, they were wrong. It was growing and growing positively by 1.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had 10 years and you have failed.

—When the Budget is released tonight, you will see the Government's forecasts for growth over the course of 1992-93 as the economy continues to gather pace. But the notion that we should restrain it to some low rate of growth so that we maintain a permanent pool of unemployment, in the wickedness of such a policy, in the cynicism of such a policy—

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of reports alleging that there has been little or no structural reform in Australia over the last four to five years? Can the Minister advise the House of the validity of these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some claims that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition along the lines referred to by the honourable member for Scullin. These are claims which fly totally in the face of the facts as to what has been happening in the Australian economy in recent years. Last week the Leader of the Opposition, in a speech he gave to an economic forecasting conference, said:

ANSWER.PARA: There has been little or no structural reform in Australia in the course of the last four to five years.
He then went on to refer to a couple of areas where it has been said there have been some. He said:
At best, these improvements have been marginal and compared to the performance of other countries in our region and more generally internationally our performance has been markedly off the pace.

It is just an extraordinary, indeed a preposterous, statement for anyone to make—particularly from one who aspires to be the Prime Minister of this country—that what has been happening in this country in the last few years represents little or no structural change. Where the hell has he been in the last few years? If he had got out of his cloistered environment, with his multimillion dollar houses and his half a million dollar cars, and had a look at the real world and what is going on out there—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—he would have seen that there has been a dramatic structural change taking place—a structural change that has been made necessary—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—by the fact that for three decades the Party of which he is now the Leader presided over this country in government and did nothing about making this country an efficient, competitive economy, and took us towards the end of this century with a blatantly inefficient, non-competitive economy, unable to take its place in the world economy with the living standards we have enjoyed in the past. It has been this Government that has picked up the ball and run hard with it in making the structural change.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at some of the things that have happened in the last few years which are important measures of structural change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, one million out of work.
—Order!

—Inflation is now 1.2 per cent. It is a tenth of what it was when we came into office. It is well below the level of our major trading partners and we have union agreement that it should stay below the level of our major trading partners.
—Oooh!
—Order! There is far too much noise.

—Our wages system, stemming from the accord, has been driving workplace reform for years now—since 1987—with the two-tier system, the structural efficiency principle of 1989, and the efficiency bargaining principle of last year. These are all operating to increase productivity and efficiency in the workplace of the nation. Productivity is improving. The national accounts show that in the last year productivity for all industries increased by 1.6 per cent at a time when GDP increased by 0.4 per cent. In the non-farm market sector, it increased by 2.6 per cent. So we are experiencing strong growth in productivity even when the economy has been at low levels of activity. Industrial disputation is 61 per cent lower than it was under the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: In education, retention rates for those in year 12 have gone up, so we are skilling our future work force much more than was ever done before. We have doubled the retention rate to year 12, and there has been a 60 per cent increase in the number of students in university education. In One Nation and the youth statement we have committed ourselves to a greatly expanded activity in vocational education and training, including a new system of entry level training based on competency-based training.

In research and development, Australia's real growth in business research and development expenditure from 1983 to 1990 was 12.7 per cent per annum, the second highest in the world in that period. The growth in the number of patents issued in that period has also been the second highest in the world. In relation to tariffs, no other government has picked up the ball, except the Whitlam Government, and done something about reducing the tariff levels in this country. We have done that and are pressing on with responsible policy in that area.

Our manufactured exports have been growing at a very rapid rate. Over the last six years they have been growing faster than those of any other OECD country. We have twice the OECD average for growth in manufactured exports. Elaborately transformed manufactured exports have quadrupled in our period of office and have gone from 12 per cent to 18 per cent of exports.

The recent EPAC paper demonstrated very substantial progress in productivity in our government business enterprises with an increase in productivity of 46 per cent between 1984-85 and 1990-91. EPAC says that although our GBEs started well behind scratch, by the second half of this decade their productivity will be at world levels.

Because of our deregulation of domestic aviation in November 1990, our aviation industry had amazing growth in 1991. While every other country was experiencing downturn, our fares fell by 32 per cent and our passenger traffic went up by 30 per cent.

In telecommunications, we have broken the Telecom monopoly and we have put a new operator in place. In 1993 a third mobile operator will come in. Telecom prices are restricted to the CPI minus 5.5 per cent which at present CPI levels means that real prices are falling considerably.

In waterfront and shipping, which has been taken as the real sine qua non of the test of structural change, we can see very substantial reforms in place. In container terminals, the average number of containers per man shift are up 100 per cent over the last two years. Crane handling rates are up by almost 60 per cent since 1989.

—Stevedoring charges fell 38 per cent between 1985 and 1991. With bulk cargoes, the grain handling labour requirements fell by 50 to 80 per cent in the last year and a half; that is, the turnaround time was halved. On our ships we have seen a 40 per cent reduction in the average size of crews since 1983 with three-quarters of that fall since 1989.

The decisions that they were rolled on were the float of the Australian dollar; the removal of exchange controls; the reduction of the tariff wall; the shifts in fiscal policy; the change in the factor shares between wages and profits; the reformation of the tax system to give us a decent income tax regime which is not haemorrhaging all over the floor with bottom-of-the-harbour-type schemes and the rest; the absence of capital gains taxation and the double taxation of dividends; the changes in the waterfront, which nobody attempted in 30 years of coalition government; the changes in telecommunications, which nobody attempted in 30 years of coalition government; the shift to exports to elaborately transform manufactures, which this Government has presided over; and the 300 per cent increase in manufactured exports since 1983. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the reports in the paper. They are totally without foundation. They were made by the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, Wal Murray, a person who, I think, is known very well by those on the other side of the House. ANSWER.PARA: There is a solution—a very simple solution: that is to get the hell out of Hume and Riverina.

He is the one to whom is attributed this quote that I have reneged on some package that I negotiated with the States. That is interesting because Wal Murray was not even at the meeting, and it is interesting because it directly contrasts with what the Minister for Agriculture, who was at the meeting, said in relation to this agreement. Ian Armstrong actually praised the outcome.

PARA.TAB: Not only did Wal Murray get it wrong again, but also he put in great jeopardy the early payment to drought affected farmers in New South Wales and Queensland. He also put in jeopardy the finalisation of a drought policy which I will be announcing later this week on the back of the Budget. The simple fact of the matter is that I have had the opportunity to visit the two most drought affected areas in this country—the western division of New South Wales, as well as Queensland. I understand the hardship that is being experienced by those people, and it did impact upon me very strongly. But it also provided the opportunity to have genuine discussions with the people involved to identify precisely what we could do to assist them. This is what I announced some four weeks ago as a result of an agreement that I negotiated with the State governments.

There are two aspects to the agreement. One goes to alleviating the immediate hardship for which I indicated a preparedness to provide $14m immediately—$14m which is being put in jeopardy by Wal Murray's statements, I might remind the House. Secondly, the other aspect of this was to ensure that we had a component in the drought policy which dealt with circumstances of severe drought. That is crucial to a national drought policy, and I am pleased to say that following the Budget tonight we will be able to announce a good policy direction in terms of a drought policy.

As far as the agreement itself is concerned, for the record, I agree to fund—in addition to the 50 per cent interest subsidy—dollar for dollar with the States up to, effectively, 100 per cent interest subsidy, as well as lifting the cap on the entitlement to $30,000. But I indicated to the States of New South Wales and Queensland that, because they had made money available through transaction based levies, on this occasion I was prepared to waive their requirement to match that dollar for dollar. In other words, the 75 per cent would be provided by the Commonwealth and it was a matter of judgment as to whether the States of Queensland and New South Wales would take it up to the other 100 per cent.

I am a bit disappointed that when the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey, was in the western division recently—where he announced additional support for transaction-based levies—it was clearly within his capacity to allocate that funding to take the interest subsidy to 100 per cent but he did not do that. He persisted with the transaction based approach—the very approach which even members of the National Party on the other side concede we need to get rid of in time.

But the point is that that was the agreement. The significance of this agreement can be realised when you combine it with the discussions that we have had with the banks over recent months whereby they have been prepared, in cases where the farm is long term viable and where the farmers demonstrate a commitment to increasing productivity and coming to grips with their terms of trade, to develop packages of finance for up to 30 years with interest only payments for up to 5 years. If we combine that capacity with what we have done in these extreme drought circumstances—a 100 per cent interest subsidy—we are meeting the very needs that the farm sector in the western division of New South Wales and in south-eastern Queensland has been talking about. Yet that very agreement was put in jeopardy by Wal Murray's announcements.

I have made it clear to the groups that I have spoken to in these areas that this policy is based on securing the long term viability of the farm sector and not prolonging the inevitable for farms which are not viable in the long term. I must say that even in those drought affected areas that principle is accepted by those with whom I have spoken. In terms of viability, it has to be not only economically viable but also environmentally sustainable. As an indication of this problem, in that drought-affected area of western New South Wales we have circumstances where the livestock numbers are estimated at some 8.7 million dry sheep equivalents, whereas the estimated carrying capacity is 7.7 million, which is well under that.

The fact of the matter is that this is good policy. We have come to grips with the development of a national drought policy which, as I say, will be announced, but at the same time we have given much needed relief to those farmers and to those areas that I visited and where I have taken note of it. It is sound policy. It ought to be applauded and you ought to be doing what is necessary to implement it and tell Wal Murray to pull his head in and stop jeopardising it.

—An incident at Parliament House on 12 August 1992, in which a four-wheel drive vehicle was driven through the main entrance of the building, has received a great deal of media attention. As honourable members may be aware, a number of agencies are involved in providing security in the parliamentary precincts. The President and I decided that an expert who was not attached to any of these agencies was required to provide an objective assessment of the incident and the Parliament's capacity to respond. We commissioned Mr Richard Dixon of the security division of Price Waterhouse to investigate the incident and make an immediate interim report to us on appropriate means to prevent a recurrence of such incidents.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dixon, who is a retired commander of the AFP, presented his report yesterday. A copy of the report has been made available to the party leaders and to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) on a confidential basis. The two Ministers are the Ministers who are nominated by the Government as the Ministers responsible for liaison with the ministerial wing and with the APS.

The report finds that the actions of the security staff in detaining the driver of the vehicle and evacuating the public from the building were proper and effective. The driver has appeared before the ACT Magistrate's Court on four charges relating to the incident and has been remanded in custody pending the receipt of a psychiatric report. Mr Dixon's report contains recommendations for the installation of temporary vehicular barriers at the entrances to the building. As honourable members will be aware, the barriers are now in place.

There will not be any overreaction to the incident by the President and me. The measures the President and I have put in place will not inhibit in any way the public's access to Parliament House. We have been very careful to ensure that the balance between open access and effective security is maintained.

Mr Dixon's report makes other recommendations in relation to the installation of more permanent barriers, the strengthening of building entrances, the management of security, the powers of attendants and emergency evacuation procedures. The President and I are considering these recommendations. In the light of the report, the President and I propose to commission a wider review of the protective security of Parliament House, which will include an examination of the risks to the building and its occupants, and the effectiveness of current arrangements in protecting against those risks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by asking: who has created the large underclass of people suffering so much at this time? PARA.TAB: Two particular quotes that expose the fragile position of the Prime Minister this day, as correctly highlighted by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), concern cooking the books and fudging the figures. Back in 1982 the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Keating, told the Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Parliament: Where do we go in this nation when the principal Minister of government, responsible for the Department of the Treasury and responsible for the publication of the only document upon which the Australian nation can base some economic judgment, falsifies that document? It is the habit of this nation to have annual Budgets and Budget statements prepared by the premier department of the Government, the Treasury.
That was said in 1982. Let us look at what the ex-Treasurer said in 1992; to be precise, 24 June 1992. Mr Keating, who was speaking as the current and interim Prime Minister of this country, said:
One of the claims by some of the pointy people is that I rewrote parts of Statement No. 2. Too right I have.
He was caught red-handed. He admitted that he had cooked the books; that he had falsified the Budget statements; that he has massaged the numbers massively in recent times.

PARA.TAB: It is against that background that I think it is time we looked at seven consecutive comments from seven past Budgets of this ex-Treasurer, now Prime Minister and soon to be ex-Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Let us look at his record. In 1984 Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policies are on track.
Some track! In 1985 he said that the Budget:
. . . builds upon our very significant successes and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government.
He was wrong again. In 1986 he said that the Budget:
. . . rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.
He was wrong yet again. In 1987 he said:
Our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.

They were pivotal words in 1987. It has been downhill ever since. In 1988 the famous statement was made, and I appeal to people in the public gallery who are beyond the cocoon of Canberra to take note of it. In the Budget document of 1988, Mr Keating said:
The nation is successfully emerging from the most severe economic crisis in a generation . . . this is the one that brings home the bacon.
Some bacon! Shame on that person who uttered those words and who has failed repeatedly to bring home the bacon. In 1989 he said:
Australia will emerge . . . without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.
He made that comment in 1989, which was three years ago, on the equivalent Budget day. In 1990 he said that the economy will improve:
. . . without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

Seven times the Prime Minister has been caught out completely; seven times he has failed to deliver in terms of his own Budget rhetoric—which I accept that he wrote, and he has a right to present his Budgets in those terms. But, boy, did he get it wrong.

PARA.TAB: A consequence has been one million people unemployed. A consequence has been a nation where the foreign debt has gone from $36 billion in gross terms at the start of this Government to over $181 billion. A consequence has been that Australian taxpayers, many of whom are hard pressed and are back to being single income families just above the poverty line, have been hit by bracket creep to a collective tune of some $22 billion. A consequence has been that wholesale sales tax—the existing consumption tax of 30 per cent, 20 per cent, 15 per cent and 10 per cent, which we will abolish—has crept up and up to rest at over $10 billion, a 60 per cent increase under the Labor regime.

Then there is the fuel excise tax on poor motorists in decentralised job locations trying to get to their job or hang on to their job in so many areas where there is no public transport and where the only alternative is to use taxis. What has happened? There has been an increase from under $1 billion at the start of the last decade to a $7 billion rip-off of the motorists now—an excessive taxation on the transport industry, adding to the burden of the drought and adding to the burden on decentralised firms still trying to maintain their employment base across Australia.

If we are to make a real assessment of how our economy is travelling, perhaps we can look just briefly at Japan. It is not an exact comparison, but it is interesting to reflect that Japan has had over three times the productivity increase that Australia has had since 1983. France and Italy have had over double the productivity increase that Australia has had in that period.

The truth is that we have been marking time under Labor—and it gets worse. We have one million people unemployed. The official unemployment rate is 11.1 per cent. But in the State of Victoria it is worse. Thank God Victoria is going to the polls, although it is very unfortunate for those of us who are Vietnam veterans that it is on the wrong Saturday, on 3 October. But soon enough Kirner will be gone from the premiership of Victoria. Victoria, under a State Labor government and with a Labor government federally, has a youth unemployment rate of 46 per cent. What shame that a Labor government can deliver that outcome after having its hands on the levers.

It is also interesting to pick up on a comment made by the new `El Presidente', the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) to wit, the man who came in to rescue and take over the presidency from Senator Loosley. Of course, Labor would have us believe that the rich would do far better under our policies. It is very interesting to examine the facts on this score, as `El Presidente' has done. He has admitted that the gap between the rich and the poor has got worse under the 10 years of hard labour that we have been subjected to in this country. None other than the honourable member for Lalor has been honest enough to admit that the gap between the rich and the poor has deteriorated, has worsened greatly, under Federal Labor.

Since this Government came to power, single income couples on average weekly earnings have had a 4.7 per cent decline in their disposable income. Interestingly enough, single income couples on six times average weekly earnings have had a 6.7 per cent increase in real disposable income since Labor came to power. So much for Labor's rhetoric!

We are the ones with the fair dinkum policies that will provide equality. We are the ones that will get the monkey of the huge fuel excise taxes, the rip-off of every motorist in this country, off the backs of people and save them $11.40 every time they fill up an average fuel tank.

It is this Government that has maintained secret consumption taxes of record proportions in Budget after Budget yet has the audacity to come in here and argue against our fair dinkum, fairly based and fairly structured policy to abolish seven taxes and replace them with one, fair, GST—a path which, incidentally, 59 other countries have gone down with considerable success.

I just add that Australia is one of the few countries persevering with a payroll tax. Here in Australia we have one million unemployed—massive unemployment right across the country—very little change, fragile economic growth and not enough to soak up that unemployment, yet the Government perseveres with a payroll tax. We provide the remedy to abolish totally all payroll tax.

So Labor's historians will have to explain the crippling debt, the incentive sapping taxation, the low productivity, the distribution of income away from average wage earners, favouring the rich, the chronically high unemployment and the underclass that the Prime Minister created—the underclass that this country did not have to have—in the same way as he created the recession that we did not have to have.

Ten budgets have greatly failed Australia to the extent that the big swing is on. In Victoria, we could even see a State seat such as Footscray go. Federally, the seat of Gellibrand could go to the coalition. Not one Labor member deserves to keep his or her seat in either the Victorian State Parliament or the Federal Parliament except for one, and I will tell honourable members who. I am prepared to make one exception: the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who had the courage to attack the Prime Minister last week in such a way that I thought we might even send him a National Party membership form.

No-one can deny that international factors impact on the Australian economy, but the level of incompetence of the Prime Minister has greatly added to that burden. Those figures are pretty serious. The steel industry in Japan last month reported another savage downturn, and that is going to have huge implications for the Australian economy. But what I will never forgive Labor for is keeping those interest rates so high and for so long. It was so arrogant and so out of touch. The Prime Minister boasted he had his hands on the levers of the economy. He got it totally wrong, and the one million unemployed are paying the price. The sooner the Prime Minister loses his job so that one million Australians might have a chance of getting their jobs back, the better for all of our sakes.

I now turn to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald last week. Even the Government has now walked away from those One Nation predictions. It has seen its One Nation statement go up in smoke. But, more interestingly, I point to the fact that the economic model on which One Nation was based has now been put under wraps and the public have been denied full access. Why? I quote from the same article:
It has since been decided that this cannot be done, sources revealed, because it would show where the numbers were massaged.

That is, massaged by the Keating prime ministerial office. The article detailed the Prime Minister's disbanding of the national income forecasting committee when he was Treasurer and its replacement with the joint economic forecasting group. It highlights the politicisation of this group and the way the figures were rewritten and rewritten, Budget after Budget.

PARA.TAB: So what we can expect tonight is the great fudge once again, the great rewrite once again, the great falsification of what ought to be fair dinkum forecasts for the benefit of those who have to deal with the economic circumstances and the horrific drought which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) referred to in Question Time. I say to the Government and to the Minister that I accept that drought is beyond the direct control of government—clearly, the weather is—but there are ways and means of pursuing those policies which will minimise that effort. But I put it to those opposite and to the House that they are exacerbating the burden of the circumstance by their failure to adopt the fundamental reforms which would greatly ease the burden of taxation on hard-pressed, drought stricken farmers, primary producers, exporters, small business operators and the like.

I go back to that clear-cut example: even in drought, farmers are greatly exposed to the horrific cost of transport to cart fodder in and to cart livestock out to agistment and the like, and there is some specific assistance available to them. I simply say to the House that this Government has had its chance. Enough is enough. It is time for a change. We need to remind ourselves of the fact that, whilst we have a drought and have had one over the course of the last couple of years, it is nowhere near as widespread as the drought in 1982-83. But other factors that have impacted upon the farm sector have caused severe hardship and real difficulty. It is against that background that I set about using the existing mechanisms available to government, knowing that there was a reluctance on the part of the State governments to do much else than blame the Commonwealth for not spending enough, and to try to find the flexibility within the rural adjustment scheme which provided substantial resources to assist farmers in hardship for whatever reason, but including drought.

There was a substantial injection of funds into the RAS. Substantial new flexibilities were introduced into the interpretation. There was the deadlocked agreement broken by me with the States in getting part B activated. I would simply remind the House that, for all the bleatings that the Leader of the National Party in New South Wales goes on with about the amounts of money that it has spent on drought, the fact of the matter is that the New South Wales Government has still spent only just over half of its 1991-92 allocation of $8.4m under part B of RAS, which is intended to provide the very means of carry-on assistance that farmers affected by drought require.

I would suggest to the House that the reason why this has not been spent is that the New South Wales Government has to match $1 for every $2 of ours expended under part B. We have heard a lot of talk this afternoon about the definition of the word `hypocritical'. That must go down as one of the most hypocritical statements by the National Party and the New South Wales Government in trying to pass the buck to the Commonwealth but not exercising the opportunity available to it to provide the fullest amount that we have made available, when we have been prepared to double the contribution as against its $1 of contribution.

I also point out that we have provided close to $50m in 1991-92 through RAS support for farmers in New South Wales. In addition to that, we introduced the new income support approach for farmers who could not incur any additional debt but who needed to get food on the table. When I visited the western division of New South Wales, I was applauded by a very large meeting that gathered in Bourke for having introduced that initiative. Despite the press releases that are put out from time to time by the National Party saying that this has not worked, the fact is that it has targeted real need and it is well regarded by those who have been recipients of it.

The reason we had to change drought policy is that in 1989, after a report into the then current drought arrangements, there was unanimous agreement that the policy had to change. Why? There are two basic reasons: firstly, the previous system had been rorted and no more had it been rorted than in the State of Queensland under a National Party led by Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Honourable members should remember that most of his Cabinet are now disgraced because of the way in which policy had been run in that State. The policy on drought was rorted. Just to give an instance of this rort, we had the circumstance in some shires in Queensland where between the years 1964 and 1989-90 areas were drought declared 70 per cent of the time. The focus of those recipients of drought benefits was a very small group compared with the overall farming community.

Secondly, the transaction based subsidies which the States still want to continue do not discriminate on the basis of need, nor do they encourage farmers to make provision in the long term, to treat drought as a natural recurring feature and to adopt risk management policies. The policy has to be changed not just because of the rorts but because the policy thrust has been bad. We have to treat drought as a naturally recurring event; we have to convince farmers to prepare for that event; and we have to equip them with the wherewithal to do it.

There is no disagreement, from all the farm leaders I have spoken to, about the general direction, although there have been difficulties associated with implementing a policy to reflect those factors. The two sticking points are, firstly, how we deal with the circumstances of extreme drought and, secondly, how we come to grips with the new funding arrangements under the rural adjustment scheme, given that that will be the centrepiece of the delivery of drought and other assistance.

I am pleased to advise that, finally, at a meeting recently held with agricultural Ministers we reached an in-principle agreement which is subject to announcements that will be made tonight within the Budget. I undertook to go back to Cabinet and argue for these commitments. I believe that as a consequence of the Budget tonight we will finally be able to announce a drought policy for this country in the immediate future. It will be a drought policy based on sound policy initiatives which have been talked through with the constituency and which complement the thrust of economic and long term viability, better and more sustainable land management practices and the initiative that we recently announced: the landcare and environment action program for the young unemployed in this country. The policy is to put a labour component, together with the capital dimension that is there, to address these landcare and environment related issues to make our rural system more sustainable. We will also announce changes in the not too distant future to RAS to make sure that it goes in that direction.

I am disappointed that the Leader of the National Party did not give us an insight into the Opposition's drought policy. Those opposite seem to think that the GST and Fightback are a panacea for everything, but Fightback does not even mention drought. To suggest that to eliminate taxes will solve drought problems is arrant nonsense.

I turn now to the assertion that the abolition of seven taxes will be a great boon to the rural sector. I have already abolished one: the coal export duty. Apart from the fact that that reduces the taxes from seven to six, it does not mean terribly much for the rural sector. When have those opposite gone out and told the farmers, `We have got a great deal for you. We are going to abolish the coal export duty.'? The farmers would just look at those opposite stupidly, and they deserve to be looked at stupidly. Of the remaining six taxes, three predominantly will not apply to the farm sector: payroll tax, superannuation and the training guarantee levy. Why? Because farmers in the vast bulk of cases do not pass the thresholds that require those taxes to be paid.

Of the three remaining taxes, we will exempt one almost entirely with the amendments that we have made to the wholesale sales tax. The wholesale sales tax is now only one per cent of the cost of production for the farm sector. The big benefit that is proposed for the farm sector is the fuel excise. But the question still remains: how will the coalition fund its roads program? Abolishing the fuel tax will cost the Budget $6.8 billion. One either has a great gaping fiscal hole—and those opposite have talked this afternoon about the need for fiscal responsibility—or one has to raise the revenue through other road user charges. Yet the Opposition still has not come clean and said which of those options it will exercise.

Fightback is quite clear: Fightback says it will be done through a user pays principle. The NFF analysis that has been through the ACIL report assumes kindly, I would suggest, that only 50 per cent would be recouped. What does that mean for users of diesel consuming equipment who do not pay any excise now but who will be slugged with the road user charge to meet the shortfall? Why have members of the National Party not told their people about that?

The last of the remaining so-called seven taxes is the customs tax. The customs tax and the issues that relate to it are causing enormous difficulties for the National Party, as it well knows. It has already had a resignation from the front bench. The tax can only be abolished if all tariffs are also abolished. We know that the Opposition has been agonising about the difference between negligible and zero. We have heard the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewston) argue that protection support or support in lieu of the tariff can be given through the exchange rate, and we have seen a good example of how that might happen in recent days.

I would be very surprised if farmers really believe, on the Opposition's say so, that their industries will be looked after by the exchange rate because, every time the exchange rate is mentioned to me in meetings, farmers say that they do not have faith that it will take account of their concerns. The point remains that we cannot get rid of the customs duty unless tariffs are abolished. The Leader of the National Party needs to contemplate this point very carefully. He is either stuck with his commitment to zero tariffs or he cannot deliver on one of those tax cuts. That is what he is stuck with.

I turn now to the impact micro-economic reform has had on the farm sector. We have heard today that nothing has happened. We have had a good response from the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) on that point. I will mention some specific areas that have had an immediate and lasting impact on the farm sector. In shipping, the average crew size has been reduced from 33 to 21 since the end of the last recession. That has seen a reinvestment in this country of $2 billion in Australian flag vessels. Five years ago that would never have been thought possible, but it has occurred because of our commitment to and delivery in shipping.

In waterfront reform, the Australian Wheat Board has estimated a $10m a year saving from a reduction in stevedoring costs. Australian ports are now regarded by the Wheat Board as amongst the most efficient in the world, yet the Opposition goes around saying that no reform has taken place. In rail transport, Australian National has reduced its call on taxpayers by 70 per cent since 1982-83. We also have a strategy to reduce costs in electricity and a number of other government business enterprises. It is nonsense to suggest that no reform has taken place; it has. We will continue to deliver good policy. Whilst those opposite go round with their heads lopped off not knowing where they are going, the people in the electorate will turn to us. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable pleasure that I speak to the matter of public importance submitted by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). I remind the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who has just spoken, that my speech will deal mainly with drought, as the Leader of the National Party requested this morning. This matter has not been neglected by this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has just given another one of his extraordinary speeches in which he demonstrates that he knows little about what goes on in the bush. He says that sales tax does not affect farmers at all. He has been running this line for over a year now. We have seen him embarrass himself in Question Time by saying that sales tax does not apply to two-wheel drive petrol utilities, et cetera. Treasury's own figures show that $288m in sales tax is paid by farmers. Surely the Minister cannot deny his own Treasury figures. He also tries to disparage Fightback. The Treasury document, which the Government itself set up to see whether it would benefit farmers, says quite clearly that farmers would be better off by $1,025m. That translates into $160 for the average farmer every week for the rest of his or her life. The Minister has knocked that.

I think debate in the House on a matter of public importance whereby the outright fibs the Government has been telling us constantly over the last 10 years are exposed is long overdue. The litany of deception that this Government has fed the Australian people to stay in power is a sad record. The only extraordinary thing about it is that Government members have got away with it for so long. Today in Question Time we heard the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) reeling off supposedly good thing after good thing that they have done for this country. When their answers were finished, those who had listened to them could conclude only that Australia was some sort of nirvana; that we had died and gone to heaven and everything was well. The fact is that Australia is in a very deep recession, and this is especially so in the bush.

We have record numbers of bankruptcies in this country, the likes of which we have not seen since the 1930s. We have record shortfalls in investment, and unemployment at the level of one million people. We have an overseas debt that has blown out almost seven-fold, from $23 billion net to $148 billion. The money that we send out of Australia every year in the interest payments on that is more than we are spending on health, education and defence individually. The tragic thing is that that will continue to go up for some time—such momentum has been generated by this Government's policies. On top of that, we have had record interest rates, and at present we have record real interest rates. All the Government is doing is ignoring the hardship out there. Do Government members know what it is really like?

We have just come out of the winter recess, and every day my office receives a constant trickle of people who are distressed about what is happening at the moment. These people are distraught. They do not know where to turn. Their life savings have been ripped off them by Government policies. Surely Government members know how bad it is. Surely they cannot be that dim. But they blithely go on saying, `We've turned the corner. Recovery is under way'. Does anybody actually believe that? They say, `We just want a bit more time'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time.

—It is time, but I suppose what they are really saying is, `Elect us one more time. We like the power and privilege of office. We do not know how to handle it, but we certainly like the power and privilege of it'. I say to the Government, `Your time is up. You have ruined a great country. You have poisoned almost everything that you have touched. You have run out of ideas. You are even recycling bereft policies such as using taxpayers' money to create government jobs'. At the next election there will be a cleaning out of the Augean stables in this country, the likes of which we have not seen since we were last put into power, back in 1975.

PARA.TAB: The Government has hurt so many people, and hurt them so badly, that I would think at least it would do something about it. This is supposed to be the party of compassion, but it is totally ignoring the desperate plight these people are in. No area has been hit harder than the western area of New South Wales. As my new electorate will take in 40 per cent of New South Wales, I would like to say something about that. At present, 73 per cent of New South Wales is in a drought. Most of that area is in the second year of drought and some of the area is in the third year of drought. The little bit of rain we had the other day, 50 or 100 points through most of that area, will not do much good at all.

It is not just the traditional drought that they are suffering at the moment of little water, no feed and dying stock; they are also suffering a financial drought, in large part caused by Federal Government policies. The Minister sits there looking at me. There is no better example of what the Government has done than the emasculation of the IED scheme. Had it left that intact back in 1983-84, people today would have been in a better financial position to get through the drought. The Government removed drought from the national disaster relief scheme in 1989. Despite numerous inquiries, despite a drought policy review task force reporting over two years ago and despite a Senate standing committee being formed to bring out a national drought policy, the Government is only now starting to act in this area. The drought will be over if it is not careful and does not act soon.

The Minister has allocated $14m for farmers in extreme drought in New South Wales and Queensland. I urge more Government members to get out there and see what it is really like. We just heard a speech by the Minister in which he told us how he went out there and inspected it. I was told that he flew into Bourke, was there for a couple of hours and then received a call saying he had to be back in Canberra because the Prime Minister wanted to talk to him. The reason the Prime Minister wanted to talk to him was that the Prime Minister was launching a CD that night. That was the Minister's trip into the drought-stricken area of New South Wales.

He told us that he was applauded for introducing the so-called farmer dole. I do not know too many farmers who have received it yet. There cannot be more than 80 or 100 over the whole of Australia who have received it. The scheme is just not working. The rural councillors will tell Government members it is not working. The Department of Social Security will tell them it is not working. Everybody knows it is not working, except them. If Government members do go out there and look at the drought-stricken areas, they will see that these areas are like the moon. It is the worst drought in Australia's history in many areas. I am talking about areas that normally are dry anyway.

Stock losses of 40 and 50 per cent are the norm. Some farmers are down to 10 to 20 per cent of their normal stock numbers. Imagine the trauma those people have been through over the last couple of years, seeing their average flock of 6,000 sheep dwindle, through death and starvation, to 500 or 600 today. This is the pressure that is put on families who have no income and cannot pay their bills, yet are still producing something for Australia. These are the sorts of people who may contribute $100,000 to Australia in export income, yet in years like this they themselves are earning an income of about minus $30,000.

These people have no money to start over again. The banks are perpetually screaming at them for repayments; they are falling further and further behind. Some of these people cannot even buy diesel for their generators. There are hundreds of people out there who still do not have electricity connected. In these days when we can put men on the moon, they still do not have electricity connected to their houses, even though they are making this magnificent contribution to Australia.

At the very least, I think the Government should be able to give household support in the form of a grant, as the coalition proposes. That would be much better than this farmer dole, which is nothing more than a cruel hoax. These people are now pulling their kids out of secondary school. They are suffering heartbreak. They turn on the radio to hear a bit of good news, to hear what the Government is doing for them, and what do they hear? The Reserve Bank is propping up the dollar, keeping the exchange rate artificially high so that, if they do finally get a bit of wool to sell, they will get less for it than they really should be getting. I can understand the great distress they are going through as a result of that.

The Government needs to bring in good policies, such as restocking finance, so that when it eventually rains again these people will be able to start again and make a great contribution to this country as they have done in the past. It is time for the Government to tell the Australian people the truth about what is happening, to face reality where things have gone wrong, and to have the courage to make the necessary changes. It should stop misleading the Australian people and wallowing in self-delusion and do something for Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that difficulties do come about because of drought and there is no doubt that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) is well aware of those through his visits to the western areas of New South Wales and Queensland. Like the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), I have been receiving constant reports on that area from Barry Brebner, who happens to be the Labor Party candidate for the area in the next election. He also has great concern for the farmers in that electorate.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Parkes mentioned a Treasury document from which he cited a $1,025m increase in farm income because of the GST. In fact, if we look at the farm sector we see that the total is $797m because, in the $1,025m figure, agriculture as well as forestry, logging, fishing and hunting are included. The real point is that it is incomes only; it does not take into account the expenditure of farm incomes and, of course, expenditure affects people's living standards just as much as their incomes. When that is taken into account in that document—the same document that the honourable member quoted from—we find that 60 per cent of farm households will be worse off. That is really the bottom line.

I find it quite amazing when members of the National Party get up and start talking about mismanagement, especially in relation to drought. The Minister has already alluded to the history of drought in Queensland, which is the State experiencing the most severe drought at present. Between 1964 and 1989—the Minister has spoken about this, but I think it is worth repeating—some Queensland shires were drought declared 70 per cent of the time. That is mismanagement; it is about putting resources where they should not go.

The announcements at that time were triggered by the State of Queensland under Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Honourable members should understand that three-quarters of the drought assistance went to only 16 per cent of properties. That is a problem. It was mismanagement for two reasons: firstly, that assistance was going to the bigger farms; and, secondly, because it was going to the wrong places and because those decisions had been made wrongly, those people who deserved and warranted the assistance were unable to get it at the right time because it had already gone to the wrong people. That is what inefficiency and mismanagement are all about. So when members of the National Party get up and start talking about mismanagement, especially in relation to drought, they leave themselves open to enormous criticism because of what they have done in the past.

Honourable members should think about the structural changes that have taken place in the last 10 years, the economic direction of this country in the larger scene and the potential that this has given Australia to be on the path to prosperity. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) talked about Japan, but he has started talking about Japan only in recent times. He should go back and look at Japan and other countries which have prospered since the postwar period. They prospered because their manufacturing industries went out and competed with the rest of the world. They produced goods and exported them. Australia missed the bus in those postwar years. Our secondary industry was protected by high tariff walls which produced enormous inefficiencies. Our mentality was closed: we supplied only the Australian market and, because of that, we were unable to compete on either price or quality with what the rest of the world was producing.

That is the situation in which we found ourselves in 1974, 1980 and 1982. The policies which had been pursued for a couple of decades were holding Australia back and making us unable to gain the prosperity that we should have had. But changes have taken place in Australian industry. If we look at the export figures of manufacturers we see that industry leaders are taking the initiative and are taking up the challenge. We are starting to compete in a whole range of areas.

This issue has to be looked at in a wider context. In the postwar decades, people would come along to see Black Jack McEwen and say, `Hey, we've just given the workers a rise. We can't afford to keep selling at the price that the imports are coming in at', and Black Jack would say, `Righto, we'll give you a bit more protection'. That was passed on and the people who paid for it—apart from the ordinary consumers of Australia—were, by and large, the primary producers. This is where we have changed things. If we look at the average effective rates of assistance to the manufacturing and agricultural industries between 1973 and 1991, we see that the gap has narrowed markedly from about 12 or 13 per cent to in the vicinity of 2, 3 or 4 per cent. That is real progress for the agricultural sector.

The agreement on the national drought policy is a real step forward. It says, `We are going to take a new direction; we are going to talk about planning and management on farms', rather than just give one-off handouts as the National Party would like to do. It has initiatives including funding a communications strategy for the national drought policy, funding education and training, supporting additional measures under Landcare, funding research and development, ensuring better coordination of research and development, restructuring the rural assistance scheme, implementing a revamped IEDS, phasing out State transaction-based drought assistance, and additional finance under the RAS for farmers in severe or extreme drought. That includes the $14m which is to be split between New South Wales and Queensland and which the Leader of the National Party in New South Wales has put at risk through his statements which really show a lack of knowledge of the issues involved.

In his speech the Leader of the National Party also spoke at length about an underclass and unemployment. It is interesting that the National Party is jumping on the unemployment wagon now because most National Party electorates—and my electorate is a former National Party electorate—have been suffering from—

TALK.START.PARA: —And it will be again soon.

—Now listen, I have heard stories about people doing this before. Charles Blunt who was here before used to stand up and point at honourable members on this side and say, `Hey, you won't be here'. Look where he is now. So anybody who gets into prediction in this thing is nothing more than a fool.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party got onto unemployment. My electorate, which is a former National Party electorate, along with most National Party electorates, suffers from very high unemployment. But that is not new. It has not come around with the recession. It has been there for 10 years. Were members of the National Party standing up 10 years ago and saying, `We've got high unemployment and we want something done for our electorates.'? No, they were not. They are jumping on the bandwagon with the Leader of the Liberal Party, (Dr Hewson), getting dragged along by the ear by that missionary, and they are doing it to the detriment of rural people. DEBATE.TITLE: NORFOLK ISLAND (ELECTORAL AND JUDICIAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Ms Fatin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise this afternoon to address the Norfolk Island (Electoral and Judicial) Amendment Bill. Although I have never been to Norfolk Island, I know that long ago when Captain Cook first discovered Norfolk Island he described it as a paradise. If honourable members look at the records of Captain Cook, they will find that on his travels he did not call any other place which he discovered a paradise, so it must indeed be a paradise. It is a pity that some hearings of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works were not held on Norfolk Island on occasions, because perhaps I would have been there then. One day I certainly will make it my business to go there. My parliamentary duties have prevented me from making it to Norfolk Island, such are the more pressing issues in my electorate like drought and Government mismanagement.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will enable certain residents of Norfolk Island to vote in parliamentary elections and for other purposes. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in the report Islands in the Sun: The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory of March 1991, reported that Australian citizens resident on Norfolk Island remain the only resident Australians not entitled, as a right, to representation in the Commonwealth Parliament. The Committee received representations indicating that Norfolk Islanders themselves had mixed views regarding representation in the Commonwealth Parliament. However, it concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the right to vote is an absolute right which should not be denied to those people of Norfolk Island who wish to exercise their right. However, the Committee recognises that the constitutional history of the Territory is complex and that Norfolk Island warrants special consideration in this regard. In addition, the Committee is cognisant of the strongly held views of the elements of the Norfolk Island population, most likely a majority, for whom Commonwealth parliamentary representation is an anathema.
It went on to say:

The Committee is aware that provisions exist within the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 for optional voting for the following categories: an Antarctic elector; an eligible overseas elector; or an itinerant elector. The Committee is mindful of the strongly held views and the historical reasons which make Norfolk Island a unique case. The Committee is therefore prepared to accept, contrary to the important principles which apply anywhere else in Australia, that the residents of Norfolk Island who are Australian citizens should have the right of optional enrolment. Once a citizen exercises this right, voting would be compulsory and normal provisions under the Commonwealth Electoral Act would apply.
The report recommended:

. . . the Commonwealth Parliament amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to give optional enrolment rights to the people of Norfolk Island; the electorate to which the voters would be attached to be determined on the advice of the Australian Electoral Commission.

The Government response to the report tabled on 10 September 1991 agreed that optional enrolment recognises the unique circumstances of Norfolk Island and provides those Australian citizens who wish to exercise this basic democratic right the opportunity to vote in elections for the Federal Parliament. As a result of the Norfolk Island plebiscite on voting rights for Australian citizens, the then Minister for Territories, Mr Simmons, suggested that for the purpose of Australian Federal elections Norfolk Island voters would be aligned with a single electorate, namely Canberra.

PARA.TAB: The Norfolk Island Government has lobbied against the single electorate proposal and for compulsory voting for all Norfolk Island residents. The current Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin), who is at the table, has backed down and has now introduced legislation which enables Australian citizens to enrol in an electorate of their choice. In this case she has accepted the strongly held view of the Norfolk Islanders.

The purpose of this Bill is to extend to Australian citizens living on Norfolk Island the opportunity to vote in Federal elections and referendums. This is consistent with the coalition's repeated views.

The Bill will amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to provide a form of optional enrolment to eligible Norfolk Island residents to enable them to enrol in mainland—Australian Federal or State—electoral divisions with which they can establish a connection. Where such a connection cannot be established the option of enrolling in particular Territory divisions will be available. The Bill will also amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 to allow those Norfolk Islanders enrolling in this way to participate in referendums, as required by section 128 of the Constitution. The electoral provisions of the Bill will have negligible impact on the Commonwealth revenues and expenditure.

There will also be a minor amendment to section 56 of the Norfolk Islander Act 1979 in relation to the travelling expenses of judges of the Norfolk Island Supreme Court to encompass travelling allowances and to place beyond doubt the legality of past payments of travelling expenses purportedly made under that section. The Norfolk Island Government meets and will meet the travel-related cost of judges visiting the island from its own Budget. The amendments to the Norfolk Island Act will therefore have no impact on Commonwealth revenue and expenditure. The coalition supports this legislation. It has been a fairly long time coming, but it is sensible and it has certainly taken into consideration the wishes of the people of Norfolk Island in its drafting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the general thrust of the remarks made by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) in responding to the Norfolk Island (Electoral and Judicial) Amendment Bill. I should at the outset say that there is no element of a retreat of the kind that the honourable member suggested from the proposition that was advanced for compulsory voting. The Government has never endorsed such a proposal. It was not part of the recommendations in the report, Islands in the Sun: The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory, presented by the relevant subcommittee, which I chaired, of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; nor at any stage was it an element of the Government's response to that report.

PARA.TAB: There is a degree of modification from the recommendations which were unanimously put to the Parliament by the Committee, that is, that optional enrolment rights would be provided to the people of Norfolk Island, the electorate to which voters would be attached to be determined on the advice of the Australian Electoral Commission. The basis for that was constitutional advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that it would be not possible under the Australian Constitution to provide for the right of residents of Norfolk Island to vote as electors of a State.

Since the time of the publication of our report the Government of Norfolk Island, anxious to avoid the consequence whereby electors on Norfolk Island would of necessity have to vote in an ACT division, which would have been the likely outcome of the Electoral Commission's determination, sought further constitutional advice and provided that to both the Government and to members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The thrust of that advice was that measures of the kind which the Government has now adopted were compatible with the Constitution.

I must say that I remain somewhat sceptical of that legal advice as a matter of principle, but of course there is unlikely to be any plaintiff willing to litigate the issue. It now is a measure which commands the support of both sides of politics. The Government of Norfolk Island, which has been very sensitive about this issue, is now content with the measure. No doubt any potential litigant, other than those parties, would find it difficult to establish standing to bring the matter before a court.

So in a sense we have a happy solution to a very hotly contested issue. It is difficult now, as we debate this matter before parliament, hearing the gentle remarks of the honourable member for Maranoa and the remarks that will be made in the debate later by members on both sides of this chamber, to recall some of the heat that previously existed in relation to this issue.

I now refer to the Committee's report, Islands in the Sun. The heat in the report is reflected at paragraph 7.10.2 where the Society of Pitcairn Descendants expressed in evidence the view that `. . . we do not want to be part of Australia . . . we are not Australians'. As a consequence of that assertion there were very strong representations to us that it was entirely inappropriate to facilitate in the least degree the possibility of Pitcairners or any other residents of Norfolk Island participating in Federal elections.

That required the Committee and this Parliament to reflect upon a very fundamental divergence between the wishes of probably a majority of the people of Pitcairn Island and this Parliament in terms of its responsibility to those who are not part of that majority. I will turn later to the question of the degree of strength of that asserted majority opinion, but let us concede, from the point of view of this debate today, that there still possibly remains a majority of residents of Pitcairn Island who would prefer that no person resident on that island be given the right to vote in an election for the Australian Parliament. That is a view with which the Committee could not agree, and it said so plainly and bluntly in terms that were referred to by the honourable member for Maranoa.

It is a point that I reiterate as Chairman of the subcommittee that took evidence. It seems to me that it is entirely unacceptable that any citizen of this country, no matter how remotely he be resident, no matter in what circumstance he lives, be disenfranchised from the right to participation, democratically, in the electoral processes of this country. It seemed to me an enormous blot on our democratic traditions that we had for so long facilitated a situation where the residents of Norfolk Island were not enabled to undertake their democratic rights of participation in elections to this Parliament.

That the particular circumstances of the island are very different from the rest of the country is reflected in a unique compromise which permits a voluntary enrolment rather than a compulsory enrolment, as is the case for the majority of Australian electors. The reasons for that are provided in the report. But it is very important to make the point that even if there had been only one Australian citizen on that island and not the many that were seeking to vote—even if there had been only one—it would have been entirely improper for the Committee to have reported otherwise than in the terms in which it did.

The next point I want to deal with is a little more broad. This debate today is of a somewhat narrow compass, but it leaves open the opportunity to respond to some of the other issues which were raised in the report, Islands in the Sun. This particular legislation deals creatively and successfully with the issue of representation of the people of Norfolk Island in the Commonwealth Parliament. I certainly look forward to the participation in the forthcoming Federal election of such of those members of that community who seek to participate.

But there are other elements of the report which have not been implemented and which the Government has chosen to reject. One I want to reflect on today is the recommendation of the report which would have changed the arrangement on Norfolk Island so that it would have required Australian citizenship to be a voter in or a member of the Norfolk Island Assembly.

Because of obvious existing interests, our recommendation was that those who had already acquired the right of voting but did not currently have Australian citizenship would not have that stripped from them, but in future it would be a precondition of participation in Assembly elections on Norfolk Island that electors be Australian citizens.

To put this in context, there are approximately 2,000 residents of Norfolk Island on the island at the present time. Of those 2,000, approximately 1,500 are permanent residents under the very special arrangements that exist under the Norfolk Island legislation. Approximately 550 are temporary residents. The Islands in the Sun report summarises the population as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Island has a population of some 2,000 people—the majority of whom are permanent residents. Approximately 550 are temporary residents. Forty-six percent of the permanently resident population are of Pitcairn Island descent. Australians and New Zealanders make up the bulk of the balance of population. Tourism, the major economic activity of the island, attracts an estimated 26,000 tourists each year.

As well as those currently resident on the island, there are at least as many off the island entitled to residence on the island. Estimates of those numbers are difficult to be confident of, but it was suggested to us in discussions on the island that there may be as many as 3,000 people off Norfolk Island—that is, more than twice the current number presently residing as permanent residents—who are entitled to return to Norfolk Island should they so desire. In other words, they have the right of permanent residence but they currently reside outside Norfolk Island, principally in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Taking the population groups that have been mentioned, those who are of Pitcairn Island descent are automatically Australian citizens by virtue of their birth and their ancestry; those who are Australian living on the island are self-evidently Australian citizens; but there are about 500 or so permanent residents of the island who are neither Pitcairners by descent nor Australian citizens. Principally, those people are New Zealanders.

Currently the laws relating to entitlement to participation in the Assembly elections allow for any person who has lived on the island for, I think, 3 1/2 years, and who evidences an intention to remain on the island permanently, to have the right to vote in that Assembly election. This means that approximately one-third of the effective franchise is held by non-Australian voters, principally New Zealanders. This is not part of any campaign of denigration of New Zealanders that may be part of a broader agenda for some; it simply reflects the reality of the social composition of the island.

There are some others who are of non-Australian descent who are from the United States and other parts of the world. Indeed, one of the most prominent advocates of the extreme anti-Australian sentiment that was evidenced on some occasions is the editor of the local newsletter who is a citizen of the United States. So the comments I make are not directed in any way against New Zealanders.

But it is incompatible, in my view, with the developing constitutional framework that we have everywhere else in Australia to allow non-Australian citizens to participate in the election of government authorities. We have had to deal with very hard choices in other parts of Australia, in other Territories of Australia, where there are substantial populations of non-Australian citizens who reside in those Territories; they have the rights of permanent residents but they have chosen not to take out Australian citizenship. One example is Christmas Island—and I think the same applies to Cocos (Keeling) Islands—where many people have lived for a considerable period and, because they have property in some other country which they might forfeit title to if they take out Australian citizenship, or for reasons personal to themselves, they have chosen not to take out Australian citizenship and thereby forfeit the right to participate in the assembly elections in those Territories in which they reside. It is the same now throughout the Commonwealth.

When I was a young lad growing up, it was sufficient for my parents to demonstrate that my father was a Scot; it was sufficient to demonstrate that he came from the British Empire, or from Britain, to entitle him to participate in a vote for the Federal Parliament. That changed some little while ago. More lately it changed in respect of local government elections. Before, all that was required was residency and now, of course, Australian citizenship is required as well. So there are common roles, and we now accept as a basic principle of democratic franchise right throughout this country that the rights and responsibilities of participating as an elector are conditional upon acceptance of Australian citizenship.

As our report said, the consequence of that is a very narrow one. Had our report been accepted, the consequence would have been a very narrow one. That is because we recommended in respect of those who already exercise the right to vote be grandfathered that their franchise be maintained. We felt it would be improper for the Australian Parliament to take away a right that has been conferred already, and that those persons who have exercised a right to vote should lose that vote. We were not suggesting that. But we were saying that any new residents going to the island should not gain the right to participate in the Assembly elections unless they took out Australian citizenship. So people who come from New Zealand, the United States, or wherever, should they choose to settle in an Australian Territory, do not acquire a right to determine the policies of that Territory simply by reason of their residence; they acquire that right only by adopting Australia as their new home and taking out Australian citizenship.

Notwithstanding my great pleasure in the very creditable, and I think skilled, negotiations that went on in relation to settling this question of ensuring that all Norfolk Island residents who are Australian citizens have the right to vote in Australian elections, I am still extremely disquieted by what seems to me to be an anomaly—something which is out of touch with the entire framework of our constitutional representation throughout the rest of this country, including in other Territories where similar difficulties emerge. It is now unique, and I think sadly unique, to Norfolk Island, where we still allow people to come in from other countries, to live on Norfolk Island for a relatively short period and to thereby acquire a right of participation in Assembly elections.

I will finish by indicating the distortions that are inherent in this kind of representation. In the course of our work it was put to us that our recommendations were entirely without the support of the Norfolk Island people. A referendum was held on 13 February 1991 to ask the electors of Norfolk Island the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to matters discussed by the Legal Regimes Inquiry, including the question of Federal representation, should the constitutional position of Norfolk Island be changed?

There is a great tradition throughout Australia of voting no in referendums. There was a great tradition established in Norfolk Island of voting no also. Some 82.3 per cent voted no and 16.9 per cent voted yes. If we exclude from those voters the 25 per cent who are citizens of other countries and who, therefore, would be offended by the recommendations we were putting—that is, that the enfranchisement of their fellows from overseas be no longer possible—we see that essentially there was a very mixed opinion. There would still be a substantial majority in favour of leaving things exactly as they were—a majority with whose opinions I would profoundly disagree—but it would be a very much smaller majority.

PARA.TAB: That 25 per cent of the island's population from New Zealand, the United States and other countries were able to vote in that referendum. Naturally, they voted in that referendum to support their existing interests. Their interests are often not necessarily those of the Nuffkas people who came to us privately and said that they felt that there were real concerns about their economic future, that they wanted to have a continuing sound relationship with Australia and that they were not persuaded by the kind of overheated rhetoric that was common to some of the propagandists for the anti-Australian cause. They felt that, whatever the future for Norfolk Island, it was in the interests of the people that it continue to have a healthy and sound relationship with the Australian mainland.

I conclude by commending the Government for an elegant solution to a difficult problem, but also reminding it that in my view, whilst the Bill solves one problem, another problem remains yet to be addressed.
