TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few words in the debate on the Norfolk Island (Electoral and Judicial) Amendment Bill 1992, which I welcome. There is no doubt that, given the nature and extent of feelings in Norfolk Island, it would be wrong to suggest that a measure such as this could have been introduced without significant consultation, and I want to refer to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Above all, it seems to me that the legislation has really been a product of compromise. The circumstances of allowing the people of Norfolk Island a voice in the Australian Parliament has been achieved in a way which I think is both suitable from the point of view of us in Australia and satisfactory not just to the Pitcairners but to everybody on Norfolk Island.

I do not want to canvass this matter as did my colleague on the external territories subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which produced the report Islands in the Sun—the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr)—although there is one area which I want to pursue. I refer to the last point which the honourable member referred to, which he suggested we needed to look at further—the question of future Australian citizenship.

We need to remember that Norfolk Island is a very independent community. Happily for Australia and, I suspect, even more happily for the people of Norfolk Island, Norfolk Islanders have chosen to continue their association with Australia. I think we should start a discussion on an island of this nature by remembering that in Australia we believe that people should have the right to govern themselves. It is therefore very much a matter for the people of Norfolk Island to determine the extent to which they want to maintain their association with Australia. Of course, this legislation takes that association a step further.

Over the years, the Pitcairners have felt somewhat different from other members of the island Territories of Australia—with understandable reasons. They trace their origins and situation from their transfer from Pitcairn Island. They have an entirely different right to their citizenship of Norfolk Island from other people. Indeed, one of the matters not addressed in the legislation, and which certainly generated some sympathy on my part, related to the fact that they would rather like on their Australian passports—they have no others—to be identified as coming from Norfolk Island. That might well generate difficulties, but as an individual I have considerable sympathy for the concept of Australian citizens who are residents of Norfolk Island being in some way identified as such on their passports. Frankly, I do not think that that would in any way prejudice their status.

Australian citizenship is an issue which this Parliament needs to consider in a wider debate. I am not happy about the degree to which in my view it is not elevated to a debate on what I see as the most important of all the rights that we as individual Australians enjoy. I believe, therefore, that if we are going to create a separate status for residents of Norfolk Island we will in a way be reducing that status. That would concern me. So there are two sides of the debate as far as Norfolk Island is concerned. Certainly in my view, as far as Australians are concerned, being an Australian is a pre-eminent right and privilege. I do not want anything done that would in any way introduce different classes of Australian citizenship. I guess that is one of my reasons for questioning the degree to which we could give the residents of Norfolk Island that status on their passports.

Equally, I do not know that we should impose Australian citizenship on Norfolk Island residents. It is appropriate to accept—and the honourable member for Denison has identified something of the population breakdown within Norfolk Island—that Norfolk Island is a Pacific Ocean domain. It is in a part of the South Pacific in which many other independent countries—some of which are even smaller than Norfolk Island—operate as independent nations. If Norfolk Islanders have decided to retain their association with us, so be it, but I do not believe that we should impose on them any obligation to Australian citizenship. Although I am a member of the committee which made those recommendations to which the honourable member for Denison referred, having heard the arguments of the people of Norfolk Island, I accept their point of view.

I want in particular to speak of correspondence that I have received from Mr John Brown, the Minister for Health and Education in the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island, who, I understand, has recently been elected as the Chief Minister of the Legislative Assembly. SPEECH.PARA: The question of public servants' ability to be members of the Legislative Assembly is, of course, a separate issue, and the Norfolk Island Government is very keen to ensure that the issue does not delay the progress of the electoral Bill in the form in which it was introduced.

PARA.TAB: I quote from the document titled Norfolk Island Public Sector—Proposals for Change. Under the title `Assembly members' on page 4, it states:

Norfolk Island is a wonderful spot, and one which I am sure all of us who have visited it regard as one of those delightful areas of the Pacific which, remote and isolated though they might be, have a quality of life which I suspect few others on the Australian mainland can enjoy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania?

—I think it would be better if we forgot about some of the problems south of the Victorian border and across Bass Strait. They really canvass quite different issues from those that are currently before the House. I suspect that even Tasmanians would enjoy a sojourn in Norfolk Island, as I know my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has on more than one occasion.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is to be commended. It is a welcome addition to the evolving relationship between Norfolk Island and Australia. It is one which I trust will foster our future together as citizens of the South Pacific, sharing as we do a common concern that there should be an opportunity for individuals wherever they might live, in Australia or its Territories, to have some say in electing the Government of our choice and ensuring that the members of that Government are answerable to those who are the voters and the electors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues on the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in speaking on the Norfolk Island (Electoral and Judicial) Amendment Bill. The Bill is in essence quite simple; it amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act to implement the recommendation of the report of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee entitled Islands in the Sun which canvassed the legal regimes of Australia's various external Territories. Essentially, what the Committee recommended, which is incorporated in this Bill, is that Australians resident on Norfolk Island should be given the opportunity to vote in a Federal election. This therefore puts Norfolk Island on the same footing as the other Australian external Territories, notably Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and puts its residents on the same footing as all Australians in having the right to vote. The situation was one that the Australian Parliament could not tolerate in that a group of Australians—albeit a small group; I think the permanent population of Norfolk Island is about 2,000—was unable to vote.

PARA.TAB: Even though this is a simple measure, its path in getting here has not been terribly simple. There have been two issues, the first of which was the question of whether the residents of Norfolk Island should have this right conferred upon them. There was certainly a strong feeling among people on the island that they did not want this favour, that they did not want to vote. Secondly, there was a constitutional issue as to the mechanism by which the scheme would be put into place. That has been the subject of a period of detailed consultation between the Government and the Government of Norfolk Island. In addition, a number of legal opinions, which I have had the opportunity to peruse, have been prepared by quite eminent Australian lawyers on this question of whether the scheme incorporated in the Bill is constitutional. As the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) indicated, there may be some debate on the point, and I will canvass it briefly in a few minutes; but I do not suppose that it will ever really come to be determined because, if the Parliament and Norfolk Island are happy about it, one wonders whether anyone would ever take it to the High Court for a final determination. It is in a sense, I suppose, a moot point, but an interesting point nonetheless.

As previous speakers have indicated, the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee visited Norfolk Island on, I think, two occasions—I was able to go on the second of those occasions—to speak to the residents of the island and particularly to the Government of Norfolk Island. It was an extremely enjoyable experience, and I agree with the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) that the island can be described as a paradise. Nonetheless, the reception that the Committee members received was not one that one would normally expect from the inhabitants of a paradise; I think it is fair to say that there was a feeling of suspicion, and maybe a degree of cynicism, towards the Committee, and more broadly towards the Australian Government.

Norfolk Island is unique; there is no question about that. It is, I suppose, an accident of history more than anything else that the island forms part of the Australian Territories. When the island was discovered by Cook in 1774 it was uninhabited. It was not until a prison colony was incorporated on the island in 1825 that there was permanent occupation of the island. That occupation continued for 30 years and then the first permanent—in the true sense—population arrived in 1856 with the relocation of the descendants of the Bounty who had found themselves on Pitcairn Island and who were offered, and accepted the offer, to move from Pitcairn Island to Norfolk Island.

From that point in 1856 until today, I think it is fair to say that there has remained a very strong feeling amongst those descendants of the Pitcairn Islanders that they really have no direct connection with Australia; it was only through the British Government at the time, the British Crown, placing the administration of Norfolk Island in, firstly, Van Diemen's Land, then the colony of New South Wales and finally, with Federation, Australia that they have a connection with Australia.

I suppose I have some sympathy with that view; I can understand why people feel that way. But I do not know whether those feelings in the sense of independence are related purely to the historical significance and history of Norfolk Island. Slightly less than 50 per cent of the population are the descendants of the Pitcairn Islanders; the other 50 per cent are made up roughly in proportion of half from the Australian mainland and half from places abroad, significantly New Zealand but a whole range of countries, as I understand it.

Norfolk Island is quite an affluent place; it rates quite high in a table of millionaires per head of population. There are a number of very affluent people on the island. One of the major concerns with what the Committee was doing was the sort of converse of the great catchcry of the American Revolution, which was no taxation without representation. The Norfolk Islanders tended to fear that if they got representation taxation would follow. At the time, we tried to stress to the Islanders that that was not at any stage the intention of the Committee or of any individual Committee members; we were quite satisfied, broadly speaking at least, with the level of self-government that had been attained on the island. The whole thrust of the Committee's inquiries, not only in Norfolk Island but in the other Territories, was to support the concept of self-government, to allow self-determination.

Norfolk Island, unlike the other island Territories, does have a relatively strong economic base; it can survive, to a certain extent if not a large extent, on its own two feet. It receives well in excess of 25,000 tourists per year; tourism would be the core of its economy. It is a relatively buoyant economy and it has a great deal of self-determination and a high degree of self-government. It has its own tax systems and does not rely on the Australian social security system. There is a range of basic pieces of legislation that are run purely from the island's own government and from its own resources.

However, there is still a bit of a misconception on the island as to the amount of assistance that it receives from the Australian Government. There is a somewhat jaundiced view amongst at least some islanders, and to an extent the Norfolk Island Government, that it is really completely freestanding from Australia and does not need Australia. I do not think that is an entirely valid view; certainly a whole range of services is still provided from Australia. One of the Committee's recommendations encouraged the process of cost recovery to continue. That is in both our interests and the interests of the Norfolk Island Government, which I think would support this.

There are three basic things for which the island is reliant on Australia. The first is defence, and it is obviously also in Australia's interests to continue our relationship with Norfolk Island. The economy of Norfolk Island is quite strong, but to an extent that is also very much bolstered by Australia. For instance, if someone in one of the tourist facilities on the island were to lose a job, I am sure that person would end up here looking for work. The employment opportunities on the island are not as great as we would like or as those on the island would like. If a person were to be made unemployed, I am not saying that the person would be encouraged to leave or anything like that, but there is a social security system in place here and I think there would be a tendency to move away from the island back to Australia or perhaps to New Zealand. That is a factor that is often not given due recognition by the island Government in its claims that it is able to stand on its own two feet. Largely speaking, I think it can do so. I think it should be encouraged to do so and Australia should be pulling back in terms of its administration on the island. We should be safeguarding our own interests but at the same time encouraging the process of self-government.

While this Parliament is empowered to make laws which affect Norfolk Island, Islanders have the fundamental right, I believe, to vote to determine the representatives in this chamber; that is what motivated the Committee. It was not some sort of backdoor attempt to get taxation or to change the island way of life. We are not interested in doing that. We are interested in enhancing the island way of life. We think basic rights should be common to all Australians, whether those Australians live on Norfolk Island or not.

That then brings me to the second matter. Having agreed upon the basic premise that the right to vote should be extended, the debate then turned to how that should be put into place. The Committee did not take a great deal of advice on this point, but the advice that it had at that stage was that it would be necessary for the island to be incorporated into one of the Territory electorates on the Australian mainland. We have, for instance, territorians on Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island voting in the Federal electorate of the Northern Territory. At that stage, on the basis of the advice the Committee had as to the constitutional choices available to it, it seemed to it logical that the island would have to be attached to one of the two ACT electorates and, at least in the early stages, it was determined that Canberra would be the electorate.

This caused great consternation amongst the Islanders. They believed they had no community of interest with Canberra, and I would not pretend they had. Obviously they would have no particular community of interest with any particular one Australian Federal electorate, and I accept that. They devised this scheme where, if an individual elector could establish a connection with a particular Australian Federal electorate, then that elector should be entitled to seek enrolment in that particular electorate.

The initial advice from the Attorney-General's Department was that that scheme was not going to be constitutional. At that stage the Islanders sought opinions. The first advice was obtained from Mr Bob Ellicott, who would be well known to honourable members in this House. He advised that the advice of the Attorney-General's Department was not correct, that the same sorts of provisions which allowed itinerant voting under the Commonwealth Electoral Act could allow a similar sort of scheme to apply for Norfolk Island.

A second advice was then obtained from Professor Leslie Zines, who would be well known to students of constitutional law in Australia. He is, I think, well known and is well regarded in terms of his expertise in the area of the Australian Constitution. He gave an opinion also that the scheme finally incorporated in this legislation was constitutional. Certainly there was some dispute about that to some degree amongst officers within the Attorney-General's Department and I have seen opinions written by the Chief General Counsel from the Attorney-General's Department, Dennis Rose, QC, who was doubtful whether the scheme first proposed by the Island Government would have allowed all island residents who may have wished to seek enrolment the opportunity to do so. But in the end it has been resolved.

If one looks at the Bill, one sees that if a voter cannot establish a connection with any particular mainland electorate through having previously lived there, been enrolled there or having next of kin there, then he can enrol in the division of Canberra. That covers the entire field. Under the existing provisions applying to itinerant electors, some people can attach themselves to a particular electorate. A Pitcairn Islander who was born on the island and who had never had any particular link with mainland Australia would be unable to do that, but if he wished to exercise a right to vote in an Australian Federal electorate I think he would probably end up having to enrol in the division of Canberra under the scheme.

The end result is that any person on the island who wants to vote will be given now the right to do so in a particular electorate or within the electorate of Canberra. I take particular note of the advice of Professor Zines who, I thought, prepared a very thoughtful opinion on it. I certainly am not going to hold myself up as a person to argue the toss with such an eminent Australian academic lawyer. But, given that I doubt it will come before the High Court anyway, and everyone involved in the scheme is happy with it, so be it: I think it is a good outcome.

Finally, I hope that the whole process has been a fruitful one. I think it has shown a reasonable level of maturity both on behalf of the Norfolk Island Government and also the Minister and the Australian Government to be able to negotiate these things through and come to a suitable solution to a difficult question. In the end I think it is a good result for the Islanders in that it recognises their particular circumstances. It also is a good result for the Australian Parliament in that we have maintained our legitimate interest in making sure that the right to vote is extended but in a way which the Norfolk Island Government can live with. It is a very worthwhile Bill and I commend it to the House.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Mr Price:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing this afternoon the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill 1992 which was introduced by the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) before the winter recess. PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—With no `bungle bungles'.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will not be any `bungle bungles'. After that, with all due respect to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and his good wishes, I would rather be on the other side of the House. PARA.TAB: It was interesting: I got the news at 3 o'clock in the morning in Johannesburg during a one-week visit to look at South African matters. I would like to pay tribute to Fred Chaney's contribution to the Senate, to the House and to Australian life generally. He is one of the most civilised people to have entered this Parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —How old are you, Jim?
—I am 57. There is no age discrimination in the Opposition and I am full of beans and ready to get stuck into this wonderful portfolio.

PARA.TAB: You will be pleased to hear, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I now intend to turn to the Bill. I will stay within the Standing Orders so that you do not have to exercise some kind of discipline over me before the major event that is supposed to occur tonight. This Bill transfers the management of marine reptiles and mammals from fisheries to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I say at the beginning that the Opposition is pleased to support this proposal.

Sea snakes, seals and birds of the sea are already protected under the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations. Turtles, crocodiles and dugong will soon be added to that list and whales and dolphins are already protected under the Whale Protection Act 1980 by the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Thus under these measures all marine reptiles, birds and mammals will receive protection in Commonwealth waters under legislation administered by one body, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Much of the enforcement of these regulations is delegated to State fisheries or conservation agencies. We note that the powers of enforcement are consistent with those applying under the Whale Protection Act and there is the same level of stringency in this protection as under the old Fisheries Act which was used to protect these species.

Reference to the Whale Protection Act leads me to remind the House that this was one of the many significant environmental advances made by the Fraser coalition Government, of which I was a member. I say to those who might have noted that I have taken a very strong interest in economic affairs over the last few years, because of the circumstances that have faced Australia, that I would like all those interested in this portfolio to know that I was a very strong supporter of the environmental measures taken by the Fraser Government. I think all those who were connected with them can be proud of their achievements.

I have had a very longstanding interest in environmental issues concerning not only the natural environment but also the man-made environment. Those bodies and groups that wish to put forward proposals within this area will certainly find an open door with me. Like my predecessor, the honourable member for Pearce, I will be absolutely straight with all parties—that is, whether they be developers, miners, conservation foundations or any of the various groups with a legitimate interest in development and environment, they will all get the same message from me. They will not get selective messages at different times.

On the question of the Whale Protection Act, from which the actual policing arrangements are drawn for this measure, I remind honourable members of the introduction on 23 April 1980 by my then colleague the Hon. David Thomson, Minister for Science and the Environment, of the Whale Protection Bill 1980. I quote from his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government—
that is, the Fraser Government—

commissioned an independent inquiry into whales and whaling headed by Sir Sydney Frost. The report of the inquiry was tabled in Parliament on 20 February 1979. On 4 April 1979, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that the Government had accepted all recommendations made in that report. The central conclusion accepted by the Government was that the Whaling Act 1960 be repealed and that we pursue a vigorous and active policy for the protection of whales. This Bill introduces such a policy for all cetaceans, that is, whales, porpoises and dolphins.

It was a matter of some amusement in the party room at that time, as I recall, because there were some members who did not know what a cetacean was. They thought it was something pinned on a jacket, but there were some of us who had been to school and knew about those things from way back. I quote again from Mr Thomson's speech:

The Bill prohibits the killing, capturing, injuring or interference with cetaceans in the 200-mile Australian fishing zone and by Australians domiciled in Australia and Australian vessels and aircraft and their crews beyond the 200-mile Australian fishing zone, with penalties up to $100,000. Support for a total worldwide ban on whaling will be sought through international forums, such as the International Whaling Commission.

It has been quite interesting in recent weeks to see a resurgence in some quarters of attempts to begin whaling again. It is interesting to remember the struggles that went on at that time, which were successful, and the very strong actions taken by the Fraser Government for the protection of whales.

PARA.TAB: The protection of these other species of the sea fits into that category. The enforcement mechanisms that were put in place by Mr Thomson at that time, using the National Parks and Wildlife Service as the protective instrument, have been adopted for this measure. So it is with particular pleasure that on behalf of the Opposition I give my full support to this Bill.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, the honourable member for MacKellar (Mr Carlton), to the portfolio area. It is one in which I have had an interest for a while, although my interest has now been taken elsewhere—to health, housing and community services. I too would like to thank the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) for his contribution because I always thought that he added considerably to debate in the place, although I am sure that the new shadow Minister will also add considerably to a most important area of debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank the Opposition for supporting the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill 1992. It is a simple amendment mainly to ensure that marine reptiles, birds and mammals will now be protected under a new Act. The Government found, after the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) had discussed the matter, that it was not sensible for the management of mammals and marine reptiles to be controlled under commercial fisheries legislation and that responsibility for those animals should be transferred to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Of course, the range of offences and penalties and so on are set out in that Act.

One of the main purposes of the amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act is to extend the application of the existing powers to the waters of the continental shelf and the Australian fishing zone. I thought I might spend a little bit of time on a matter that really arises from this because we can have specific legislation which seeks to protect valuable and perhaps endangered species but we are finding that one of the greatest threats to these sorts of species is, in fact, introduced species such as feral animals.

There has been a great deal of concentration on the eradication of feral animals. The Brisbane Courier-Mail featured an action in which the Army partook recently in the Diamantina River in far western Queensland where the State Minister for conservation, Pat Comben, had arranged with his officers and the Army to undertake the eradication of some feral cats.

It might be worth showing some of the illustrations of how we need to tackle the problem of the eradication of introduced species. They have become a direct threat to native species of animals because they may be predators of those animals, or they may ruin the habitation of the local environment and indirectly threaten the native species, not to mention their threat to native plant species when they dig them up or root them out. There are some quite extraordinary numbers. I will run through some of the species of animals that are of concern to us and are being destroyed under Commonwealth programs and in conjunction with State programs. In the Courier-Mail of 13 August this year, Brian Williams, a journalist who travelled to the Diamantina River, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Army sharpshooters have killed 420 feral cats in just three days in Queensland's far west.

He reported that they are undertaking this activity on the open Mitchell grass plains along the Diamantina River. He said that this was done in conjunction with Queensland National Parks and Wildlife researchers who themselves were out shooting cats. I would not have thought that what we think of as the domestic cat could possibly survive in that sort of environment, but some of the cats have been weighed by National Parks officers at over eight kilograms. They are certainly doing very nicely out of either attacking and devouring native species or at least denying those native species other sources of food. As I said, that Army exercise was done in conjunction with the departmental staff of the State environment Minister, Pat Comben.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, there was this coincidence of a rat plague. The cats had built up their numbers on the backs, almost literally, of the rat plague. The concern now is that, as the rat numbers are weakened and they are destroyed through drought in the western districts, the cats will turn their attention more directly to the native species. This article lists some of the species that will be further threatened by feral cats: the bilby; the kowari, which is a marsupial mouse; the plains wanderer, which is a grasslands bird; and possibly the yellow chat, which is a small ground-feeding bird. These feral cats are known to hunt each of those animals. That is of great concern.

A further interesting statistic quoted here is that people from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service have indicated in their research that one domestic cat left uncontrolled might kill an average of 25 animals each year. Let loose, the humble cat gone feral can have a very widespread and devastating impact on any number of endangered species. It is important that the Commonwealth, in conjunction with the States, improve, as it has in the last few years and will continue to do, its intervention in this area such that we can kill off some of these animals.

Recently I looked at a report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory, where different species of introduced animals are having a very large and devastating impact. This report of June 1991 referred to a number of Commonwealth programs which were aimed at eradicating some of the larger feral animals in this area, mainly water buffalo and pigs. I will refer to some advances in this area as well.

The report includes an example of control taking place in Kakadu National Park through the Commonwealth brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. Through that campaign, the Commonwealth has funded the removal of approximately 100,000 buffalo and cattle from Kakadu National Park since 1979 and about four and a half thousand in the last year. We have now reached a point at which the density of these beasts is about one beast per 100 square kilometres. We are approaching a point at which it is not so much hard to find them; rather, we are receiving diminished returns to scale for our effort. We have got through these animals in very large numbers. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: We are suggesting that there are now very low buffalo numbers in Kakadu National Park—around about 500 to 1,000.

There has been a considerable reduction of those introduced species. The report also mentions feral pigs, to which I have a couple of references. There have also been some great gains. The major infestations of feral pigs have been greatly reduced. I understand there is no separate strategy for the control of pigs unless there have been infestations detected in areas of high public use or where there is good access.

PARA.TAB: We have to be very careful about the methods we use to cull these animals. Recently I read a report which said that we might set traps for, or poison, feral pigs just out of Canberra, where there is quite a large pig population. That works well there, but in the Northern Territory—certainly in the Kakadu region—we have to be extremely careful because the Aboriginal population hunts feral pigs as a source of protein. We simply cannot be using poisons as a means of eradicating those animals. We have to be selective about the means of destroying them. The buffalo and the feral pig are probably the major destroyers of land, certainly in the northern areas.

The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, which reported in June last year, gives us an indication of this destruction. The report contains a quote by an officer of the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries who evaluated the environmental threat in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Buffalo and pigs are the most environmentally dangerous. Pigs probably will have to rate above buffaloes now and this is likely to be the case for the next 10 to 15 years. In central Australia, rabbits are the most dangerous, followed by horses. It would be fair to say that rabbits would be far and away the biggest problem. . . Foxes are also significant.

There has been considerable debate over Fraser Island, which is in my neck of the woods, up from Brisbane, where a very small number of brumbies have been running wild for some years. Inevitably debate pops onto the TV screens from time to time whereby animal welfare rightists want to save those brumbies. But those brumbies can be very destructive to growth around fairly unstable sand-dunes. If they are not destroyed, there will be some destruction on the sand-dunes. We have to make choices. I would find the choice fairly easy. We would have to destroy the brumbies in this instance. I would not like to be the one to have to do it. I am a bit squeamish when it comes to the destruction of any life.

PARA.TAB: The way in which animals can destroy habitat is also worth looking at. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service gave evidence to the Senate Committee that the water buffalo, in particular, presented an unacceptable environmental threat in Kakadu National Park. It described the potential of the impact as devastating. The Service then listed the environmental impacts of the buffalo. It is worth while using this illustration. They included:

SPEECH.PARA: .vegetation damage through grazing and trampling;
.soil compaction;
.saltwater intrusion into low-lying freshwater swamps through breaching of natural levee banks by swim channels;
.wallowing and erosion;
.siltation and pollution of water bodies;
.noxious weed dispersal; and
.impact on other animals through modification of habitat.

Those are the ways in which these animals are destroying habitat. The number of threatened native species in this area is very significant and this presents us with manpower and funding problems. We have to have sufficient programs, sufficient people and the right means of destroying these animals before they have such an impact on this area that we may in fact lose for all time certain species of animals that are reliant on the same environment.

PARA.TAB: An article from the Northern Territory Conservation Commission which appeared in the Northern Territory News of 20 June this year indicated that `Wild pigs first came to notice in the Territory in 1827'. So these animals have been with us for a considerable time and, as far as we can tell, their numbers have not been threatened until the last few years when officers have informed governments of their enormous impact.

Many animals of the Australian arid and semi-arid zone in the north are threatened by these larger animals. These include: the inland western quoll, the long tailed dunnart, the numbat, the western barred bandicoot, the banded hare-wallaby, the pebble-mound mouse, the sandhill dunnart and so on. As far as I am aware, each of those animals is a very small and fragile animal which can be destroyed very easily by larger animals. They will certainly be affected in as great a number as there is by any destruction of their habitats, and these native animals are subject to destruction.

We then turn to the debate that we often have across the chamber—perhaps more with National Party members—as to whether a government ought to declare wilderness areas where, if unchecked, feral animals can run amuck. The farmers may say, `Look, isn't it better that farmers might be able to assist in the destruction of feral animals by running cattle or whatever into an area?'. There is also a debate about competition for food between cattle and sheep and feral and native animals. We have had that debate in this chamber from time to time. But the officers of the Northern Territory Government made an interesting point about the question of how many animals were being stocked in an area. Mr Davis of the Northern Territory Government—I do not know which department—explained the point and said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, there are properties that are running large numbers of ferals and trying to ignore the fact that there are those numbers of ferals. They are saying, `This property can run 40,000 head of cattle', and they are running 40,000 head of cattle when in fact the total stocking [with feral cattle or cattle equivalents] is probably 120,000.

We need to look at the impact of all the animals grazing and living in a particular area. We might be looking at the true impact of the domestically husbanded animals which are being carried on an area—in this case, 40,000 head of cattle—but they are in addition to other animals which are being carried there, both native and feral.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the sensitivities about who is best placed to keep feral numbers low. By and large, we have worked very closely with the National Farmers Federation, as have the conservation groups. This will not come as a surprise to the honourable member for Mackellar because he will know of the considerable liaison and discussion that have gone on between the Australian Conservation Foundation and the National Farmers Federation on all of these sorts of issues. A lot of joint work is going on which will satisfy the aims of both groups.

They seem to me to be some of the critical issues when it comes to making sure that we save native species. Although this debate started out on the question of reptiles, birds and mammals, I have chosen to concentrate on the question of land animals: feral pigs, cats and so on. I will now introduce one or two other elements from the same debate. At least one other animal is of major concern to us. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget has three fundamental objectives.
The first two are about jobs: jobs now, and more jobs in the years ahead.
When, as is the situation now, there are not enough jobs, it is up to the Government to take action; to do everything in its power to provide jobs for those Australians without work.
We have already taken initiatives to boost the economy and rebuild and modernise the nation's transport system.
We have vastly expanded opportunities for young Australians.
And tonight, as our first priority, I announce further measures to boost employment in those communities and regions hardest hit in recent years.
Many of our fellow Australians have, for the first time, found themselves out of work.
For them we cannot simply wait and hope, or engage in some economic experiment.
We must act now, and act in ways which we know will work.
These employment measures will include projects conceived at the local level, providing real work and, at the same time, enhancing facilities for many deprived communities.
The total cost will be $1.2 billion over two years.

This attack on unemployment is part of our second objective—the implementation of a comprehensive and continuing strategy which is designed to achieve around 800,000 new jobs over the next four years.

Crucial to this strategy is the maintenance of a resolve to create a dynamic and successful trading nation: a nation based on talent, ideas and innovation, with its industry employing skilled workers producing goods and services to sell here and abroad.
This resolve will be fortified by measures announced tonight to entrench an already impressive growth in research and development and in exports.
There are new initiatives in vocational training, and there is increased effort to cut the costs of Government services and to improve competition.
Our objective is to have new industries alongside the old, striving to secure a larger slice of the world market.
But this Budget—as its third objective—also confirms this Government as a caring Government, intent on pursuing its program of social reform.
Tonight I announce a major enhancement of Medicare, increased support for the aged and for those who care for them, and increased support for the unemployed.
There are new measures to improve access to more secure housing, and there is more assistance for families.
Mr Speaker, as a small nation our future depends on taking advantage of developments abroad.
And in our case we straddle two very different parts of the world.

First there is the industrialised world of Europe and North America. These countries have also been struggling with high levels of unemployment. But they have higher inflation than we have. And many have lower growth prospects.
Australia's inflation rate is around 2 per cent, about half that of Europe.
This year the Government expects the Australian economy to grow by 3 per cent, or around a third faster than Europe.

Australia is also part of Asia. Growth rates and productivity in many Asian countries are impressive. But some have inflation close to 10 per cent. Most have inflation more than double that of Australia.
With a foot in each hemisphere we can benefit from opportunities in both.
We can enjoy higher growth than is forecast for Europe and the USA, with inflation certainly no higher.
Our growth rate will be closer to Asia's, but it will come without Asia's higher inflation.
And as we commit ourselves to best practice at home, and embrace competition abroad, neither hemisphere will constrain our growth.
But these opportunities will not be handed to us on a plate.
We must seize them.
Last year was difficult for many countries. It was particularly difficult for Australia.
Recovery started during the year, but failed to gather strength in the way expected.
We all deeply regret that the growth achieved was not sufficient to prevent rising unemployment.
We all deeply regret the cost of unemployment to individuals, to families and to the community.
But regret, without action, has a very hollow ring to it.
Nearly 50 years ago, the Labor Government of John Curtin, in its famous White Paper, committed the Commonwealth to a policy of full employment.
This Government affirms that full employment must and will be our continuing goal.
Tonight I present a statement entitled Working for the Future which sets out this Government's plans for the years ahead.
The Budget has a firm and unequivocal role to play in boosting economic activity in the short term.

It does so by providing a strong but temporary stimulus, and by ensuring that Australia emerges into sustained growth, with an enhanced economic infrastructure, better able to underpin the opportunities of the 1990s.
Overall, the outlays cost of new and previously announced measures to boost the economy will be around $4 1/2 billion in the next two years.
In addition, we will allow the impact of the recession on the Budget to run its course.
As a result, the Budget deficit in 1992-93 is estimated to be $13.4 billion.
Nearly 10 years ago this Government acted in the 1983 Budget to boost the economy and to reduce unemployment.
One and a half million new jobs were created and within four years the Budget recorded a surplus—the first in nearly four decades.
The present recovery will deliver jobs. But the Government is acting now to reduce unemployment more quickly, to ease the pain and burden on Australians and their families.

Tonight I announce the expenditure of a further $742m this year, and another $467m next year, to attack unemployment at its roots—in the communities where the despair is deepest and where the pain hurts most.
The package builds on the offer from local government—the sphere of government closest to the community—to move rapidly to expand local employment opportunities.
This package for local government involves job placement, road building and repair, and a new local capital works program, together with the Landcare projects recently announced.
Its centrepiece will be the local capital works program which will inject $345m into 411 local government councils, where about 70 per cent of all unemployed people live.
The program will involve grants of between $4m and $20m for each of 23 regions hardest hit by unemployment.
There will be $60m for roads, and $154m to be spent on government and non-government schools and universities.
$188m planned for expenditure on urban development and public housing will be brought forward and spent this year and next.
Expenditures on Defence purchases and on Defence housing of $87m will similarly be advanced to this year.
These measures will also be focused in regions with high unemployment.
Labour market and training programs will be expanded, particularly to assist long-term unemployed adults and to improve workforce skills and labour market flexibility.
.Places under the JOBSTART program this year will almost double, to 104,000.
.Work experience and training under the JOBSKILLS program will be available for an additional 12,000 people over the next two years.
.An extra $92m will be provided over three years for adult training places to help people back into jobs.
.Over the next four years, we will provide English language training to 38,000 job seekers.
In all, we will nearly double expenditure on these programs this year, to $1.1 billion, and we will assist over 420,000 people.
The combined effects of these measures will see unemployment decline from 11 per cent last June to below 10 per cent 12 months from now, and keep on declining in the years ahead.
Clearly, reducing unemployment is our most pressing objective.
But we must also continue our confident resolve to build a more export-oriented nation.
The Australian economy is part way through a momentous period of transition.
We have derived enormous benefits from our abundant natural resources and will continue to do so.
But in a highly competitive world, we must increasingly turn to the even more potent talents of our people.
We are creating new strengths and new skills as we respond to changes in the world around us.
In five years, our manufactured exports have more than doubled, while exports of services have increased by 82 per cent.
This has been an outstanding achievement. Our record on manufactured exports surpasses that of the major developed countries and even the Asian tigers.
But we need to increase our total share of the world market, if our growth is not to be constrained by the subdued international outlook.
This Budget adds to new measures announced in February, to enhance the capacity of our industries to export.
$75m will be provided over three years from 1993-94 to those established and successful exporters entering new markets.
And a new working capital guarantee facility will support approximately $300m of new exports for firms short of working capital.
The Government is also to assist further the rural sector which has been badly affected by reduced world prices and severe drought.
We are reducing the costs facing all exporters—our farmers, our miners, our manufacturers. And we are working with the States to improve the interstate rail freight and electricity industries.
With the States, we are reviewing their vital water supply industry and their shipping ports, and there is more to come.
We have given the Industry Commission a new role to identify impediments restricting the growth of promising export industries. I am announcing the first group of 10 references tonight.
Mr Speaker, the capacity of our industries to compete depends on our ability to develop innovative products and more efficient production methods.

We have decided to extend indefinitely the 150 per cent research and development tax concession, so that Australia can continue to grow as one of the world's research and development centres. We have also decided to tighten up the scheme to ensure that research benefiting from tax concessions has an appropriate commercial focus.
And our great scientific institutions, such as CSIRO, will receive $31m over two years to continue building the research capacity so necessary for the challenge ahead.
Innovation springs from the arts as well as science. The Budget continues support of the film industry and increases support to the performing arts.
While the Government is actively encouraging the development of industry, this will be consistent with the preservation of the Australian and global environment.
We are allocating $107m over the next four years to industry and environment programs to foster sustainable development and to help address climate change issues.
The Government's initiatives will integrate economic and environmental decision-making.
We will improve the taxation treatment of investment for, and spending on, pollution control.
Our capacity to compete in the world, and to enjoy challenging jobs, depends greatly on the skills of our workforce.

The creation of a new Australian National Training Authority and the injection of $720m by the Commonwealth will see, in three years, over 100,000 more young Australians involved in vocational training.
And by the year 2000, we will have another 200,000 young Australians aged between 15 and 19 years at school, in college and at university.
To meet these increasing demands, the employment package I am announcing includes $60m to help the States refurbish up to 600 of their older high schools.
In higher education, the Government will establish the Open Learning Program at a cost of $53m over the next three years.

For Australians in remote communities, for those with family or work commitments, and indeed for any Australian who may not have enjoyed access to traditional higher education, this initiative will be a historic milestone in removing barriers to participation.
In short, every Australian with access to a television and a letter box can now have access to a university education.
Existing AUSTUDY arrangements will be improved, and the system of grants will remain intact.
Tertiary AUSTUDY students will have the option to supplement their benefits through a voluntary loans scheme.
Through all the improvements to AUSTUDY, about 43,000 additional students will be eligible for AUSTUDY assistance.
Mr Speaker, the co-operative development of a flexible wages policy is a key element in this Government's economic strategy.
Through its close relationship with the trade union movement, this Government has fundamentally altered Australia's wage setting arrangements.
Workplace bargaining, which links wage increases to skills formation and productivity improvement, will become the primary mechanism for wage adjustments.
Agreements between managers and workers on matters such as hours of work, penalty rates, work practices and wage rates have improved flexibility while maintaining basic conditions.
Building on this approach, the Government has proposed an alternative to a National Wage Case.

Our proposal is that minimum award rates be adjusted through supplementary payments, by an amount of $10 a week, and that workplace bargaining be the principal vehicle for wage increases in the future.
This will protect low paid workers while encouraging employers and employees to accelerate productivity gains.
This will occur in a framework of maintaining Australia's inflation rate at or below that of our major trading partners and matching international best practice.
In the 1990s, as in the 1980s, the Accord between the Government and the trade union movement will ensure that we achieve significant improvements in this economy.
This Budget is a budget of action on jobs.
It is a budget of confident resolve to continue the transition to a modern, vibrant economy.
But it remains a budget of care; care for the aged, care for the frail, and care for the disadvantaged.
In this Budget the Government is building on its proud record of social reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.
—The cost of the initiatives to which I now refer have been offset, over this and the forward estimates years, by program savings and by revenue measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Important among the changes are the Medicare reforms which the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) will announce tonight. They will guarantee that every Australian will have access to the full range of hospital and medical services on a fair basis.
An additional $1.6 billion will be provided over six years for public hospitals, subject to the States and Territories agreeing to the Government's proposals for the strengthening of Medicare.
These proposals ensure that Australians will have hospital services provided on the basis of clinical need and not on the basis of private health cover.
No longer will private patients be able to jump the queue ahead of public patients in equal need of treatment.

A program, costing $71m over two years, will ensure that waiting times for elective surgery are brought down to acceptable levels. Strategies to achieve this will include, where necessary, buying in services from the private sector.
The Government's reforms will ensure that Medicare can meet the 29 per cent increase in public hospital admissions expected over the next decade.
To fund these substantial improvements in health services, the Medicare levy will increase by 0.15 per cent from 1 July 1993.

Australians on average weekly earnings will pay about 80 cents extra a week in their Medicare levy. For this they will receive the benefits of—and improvements to—one of the best health care services in the world. This achievement is one of which this Government and indeed all Australians can be justly proud.
Last year the Government gave a commitment to provide a real increase in pensions during the life of this Parliament.
I am now announcing an increase in the single rate of pension of $6 a fortnight, and $10 a fortnight for pensioner couples, from late January 1993.
This increase incorporates the adjustment otherwise due in March 1993 and includes an additional amount.
This additional amount will be provided to the older, long-term unemployed, and to most of the unemployed with dependants.

From April next year, all full and part pensioners and older long-term beneficiaries will be eligible to receive the range of fringe benefits provided by the Commonwealth, including hearing aids and a telephone allowance.
$44m will be provided for nursing homes over the next four years and a home equity loan scheme will be established for pensioners.
Mr Speaker, the Deputy Prime Minister will also be announcing tonight a new long-term housing strategy.
One of the first steps in the strategy will be to provide an extra $24m in this year, rising to $40m in three years time, for rental housing managed by community organisations and local government.
$48m will be provided over three years to help 20,000 lower income earners buy equity in the public housing in which they live. This will also release capital to fund new homes for those in need.
And a new structure of rent assistance, to cost $71m next year, will benefit 440,000 low-income private renters, including about 300,000 pensioners.
The Government will introduce a package to improve the affordability and efficiency of child care services.

The package includes an increase in the existing fee relief ceiling of $4 a week for each child in care. And it will provide for continued operational subsidies to community-based child care centres and family day care services.
These measures will assist 135,000 families and will cost $68m over the next four years.
In a new initiative, up to $136.50 in family allowance will be available on request as a lump-sum advance to help meet unforeseen expenses.
Two years ago, the Government initiated measures to assist people with disabilities to enter the workforce and to participate fully in the community.
Tonight we are announcing further measures at a cost of $68m over four years which build on those reforms.
Additional funding of $41m over four years will be provided for respite services to reduce the burden on carers of frail aged and disabled people.
And the domiciliary nursing care benefit is to be increased to $26 a week from January next year and indexed thereafter.

The Budget provides for the policies and programs to assist Aboriginal people which the Prime Minister recently announced. It also provides a total of $19m over four years for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.
Australians living in remote areas are often disadvantaged.

The Government has thus decided to increase the income tax remote area zone rebates by 25 per cent from January next year. For people in the remotest areas of Australia, the base component will be $235 higher in a full year. Remote Area Allowances will be increased accordingly.
I now turn to revenue measures.
The major revenue initiatives include the increase in the Medicare levy and an increase of $5 a kilogram in tobacco excise.
This increase will raise the price of a packet of 30 cigarettes by up to 20 cents and reinforces our policies to reduce the health costs of smoking. It will raise $80m this year.

As part of the continuing task of making the tax system fairer, from April next year, Fringe Benefits Tax will be applied to valuable car parking facilities—mainly in central business districts—that are provided by employers to their employees.
Also, the tax benefits of limited partnerships will be restricted by taxing them on the same basis as companies.
The Budget has been framed with a realistic appreciation of the difficulties before us.
While net borrowing by the public sector is expected to be the same as last year, the Budget deficit will represent an estimated 3.3 per cent of gross domestic product.
The Government will eliminate the deficit as soon as possible. We shall introduce our announced personal income tax cuts. And the Budget deficit will fall as economic recovery strengthens.
Outlays will fall over the period to 1995-96. But in the absence of new measures, revenues are also likely to decline.

If the fiscal position nearer to the time is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure. These changes—referred to in the Budget Statements—would allow for the 1995-96 deficit to be between 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent of gross domestic product.
Australia will grow more quickly this year than last. Australia is once again on the move.
Output is forecast to increase by $22 billion this year, creating around 160,000 jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: And business investment in plant and equipment, which is crucial to long-term job growth, is expected to turn around this year, making a modest contribution to the recovery.
Low inflation will continue to be the top priority of monetary policy.
Low inflation will take pressure off interest rates and keep low the cost of borrowing to firms and families.
Low inflation will fortify our competitive position and so spur economic and employment growth.

The current account deficit is forecast to widen to 3 3/4 per cent of gross domestic product, in part owing to investment growth. This is below the levels experienced in earlier years, due in no small part to our impressive export performance.
Over the past decade, this Government has progressively reformed the Australian economy.
We are working to see our manufacturing and service sectors emulate the great record of our mining and rural industries by becoming dynamic and outward looking.
This Government also saw that our education system had to be reformed: from high schools through to universities.
With that reform, young Australians can acquire the skills necessary for the challenging jobs of the future.
The Government has reformed the capacity of the public sector to support the process of economic and social transition.
Much has already been achieved.
Australia, our companies and all working men and women are now better able to seize the opportunities offered by a changing world.
We need only the resolve to seize those opportunities.
This Budget shows that resolve.
But that resolve must continue to be matched by our care for those in the community who cannot immediately benefit from those economic opportunities.
This Budget demonstrates that care.
And while Australia is better placed for future growth as the world economy recovers, we are determined to take action to provide jobs, by using all the means at our disposal.
This Budget takes that action.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Successive governments have adopted the practice of introducing a Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet expenditures that have been appropriated by the Parliament, but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective 1992-93 Budget deficit. The Budget deficit in prospect for 1992-93 gives rise to a deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund some $6 billion greater than the Budget deficit. This situation arises because appropriations from the Fund include various items that are classified as financing transactions rather than Budget outlays, and thus do not affect the Budget outcome. These items include payments to the National Debt Sinking Fund and superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The Bill provides authority for the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures incurred after the passage of the Bill that otherwise would have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The Bill also provides the borrowing authority to cover these payments from the Loan Fund. The Bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already appropriated, or currently before the Parliament, apart from loan raising expenses, which will be small. I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge upon the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys, but simply provides the means to finance expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, this Bill deals with one of the measures relating to sales tax on swimming pools announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) this evening. It will ensure that refunds of amounts paid as sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ since 1986 are passed through to pool purchasers.

PARA.TAB: In February of this year the High Court of Australia found amendments made by the Parliament in 1986 in relation to these pools to be of no effect. The Court ruled that the amendments do not conform with a requirement in section 55 of the Constitution that laws imposing duties of excise deal with duties of excise only.

The purpose of the amendments was to overcome an anomaly in the sales tax law that some pools were subject to tax while others were exempt.An unfortunate effect of the decision, however, is that pool builders, who were able to pass on to purchasers any amounts payable to the Commissioner of Taxation as sales tax on in situ swimming pools, may have been able to get the benefit of refunds payable by the Commonwealth as windfall gains.

This Bill will ensure, in line with the refund code in the sales tax law, that there are no windfall gains and any refunds paid by the Commonwealth as a result of the Court's decision go to the person who actually bore the `tax'.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this Bill is not to deny the Commonwealth's liability to refund amounts paid as sales tax on in situ swimming pools, but rather to place a condition on the eligibility of a pool builder to a refund by requiring that, if the amount paid as sales tax was passed on to the purchaser, the refund must also be passed on.

PARA.TAB: Importantly, Mr Speaker, the Bill will also provide for the payment of interest to pool builders as compensation for any period that they are out of pocket as a result of the decision and these amendments. The proposed changes are not expected to have any direct impact on revenue because an estimate of the refunds has already been included in the base line estimates.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

RDI.ITEM.TITLE: Woollen Products Used in Parliament House

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked Mr Speaker upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

QUESTION.PARA: (1)What woollen products are used in Parliament House.
(2)What is the country where the raw woollen products used in Parliament House (a) originated and (b) were processed and manufactured.
(3)What was the cost of woollen products used in Parliament House when they were paid for.
(4)What is the total area of Parliament House which is carpeted.

(5)Did the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House receive written advice which led to the Parliament House Construction Authority electing to use New Zealand woollen products in the new Parliament House; if so, (a) what was the advice and (b) will he make a copy of the advice available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr Speaker

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is as comprehensive as the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and Joint House Department records allow. The Department of Administrative Services now has residual responsibility for Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) matters, including PHCA records and files. The answer to the honourable member's request is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)Woollen products used include carpets, drapes, wall panels, furnishing materials.

(2)The carpets in the Main Committee Room and the Cabinet Suite are of 100% Australian origin. Other carpets in Parliament House were supplied by 3 different Australian carpet companies. The tenders for the carpet did not specify Australian carpet wools. With few exceptions the carpets supplied are 80% wool and 20% nylon blend. Under the conditions of tender, companies were required to indicate the source of the materials. As the Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement with New Zealand treats New Zealand products as though they were Australian, no information on Australian wool content is available.
The Joint House Department does not have adequate information available about drapes, wall panels and furnishing materials which contain wool.

(3)The total cost to supply and lay carpets in Parliament House was approximately $4.2 million. The Joint House Department does not have adequate information available from which to determine the cost of other woollen products used in Parliament House.
(4)The total area of Parliament House, which is presently carpeted, is approximately 71 000 square metres.

(5)No. In July 1986 the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) provided advice to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House that tenders had been let for carpets in Parliament House. Following the tender assessment process it became apparent that no Australian carpet wool would be used in the building. PHCA advised the Joint Standing Committee of this situation and the decision was subsequently made by the Committee that two areas of the building should be fitted with pure wool carpets of 100% Australian origin. The areas fitted are, as stated in answer to part (2) of the request, the Main Committee Room and the Cabinet Suite. A copy of the PHC advice follows.

PARA.EMPHASIS: BACKGROUND PAPER: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE CARPETS

ANSWER.PARA: Contracts for the manufacture and installation of carpet in the new Parliament House were let by the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) earlier this year. Three separate contracts were let for carpet requirements for the building. Details of each contract package are as follows:

1.United Carpet Mills of Preston Victoria won the contract to the value of approximately $1 million for the manufacture and installation of carpet in the House of Representatives office wings (18,657m(2)).
The carpet is the be manufactured in Victoria using an international blend for the wool component (60% NZ, 20% British and 20% East Indian).

2.Corporate Carpet Installation Services (Joint Venture of Solomons Carpets of Adelaide and Feltex Carpets of NZ) won the contract of approximately $3 million for the manufacture and installation of carpet in the public and ceremonial areas of the building, the Ministerial wing and the Senate office wings (50,421m(2)). Manufacture of these carpets will be split between Australia and New Zealand. Approximately 40% of the total contract value will be Australian involvement. These carpets were tendered on the basis of 100% NZ wool, however, the contractor has undertaken to maximise the use of Australian wool within the contract price.

3.Sexton Low Trading Co Pty Ltd of Brisbane won the contract of approximately $0.2 million for the manufacture and installation of carpet for selected areas including the Senate and House of Representatives Chambers. These are hand tufted 100% wool carpets which will be manufactured overseas as there are no looms of sufficient size in Australia.

The specifications for the carpets were developed in conjunction with the Australian Wool Corporation and drew heavily on the Parliament's own experience with carpets in the provisional building. With few exceptions the carpets are of an 80% wool and 20% nylon blend.

The tender specifications dealt with fibre, blend and performance and not the origin of the materials. Tenderers were required to nominate the origin/source of the materials in their tender bids. There was therefore no restriction on the tendering of Australian wool for the wool content of the carpets.

The tender documents did not specify the origin of the wool component of the carpets. Tenders proposing Australian wool content were submitted. In general the prices submitted for such bids were 50% higher than the lowest tendered prices.

As with the other contracts for the project, the CER provisions relating to trade between Australia and New Zealand applied to the carpet tenders. This has the effect of treating NZ products on an equal basis with Australian.
DECISION TO USE 100% AUSTRALIAN CARPET WOOLS IN SELECTED AREAS

It became apparent following the tender assessment process that no Australian carpet wool would be used in the building. The PHCA advised the Joint Standing Committee of this situation and the decision was subsequently made by the Committee that two areas of the building should be fitted with pure wool carpets of 100% Australian origin.

The JSC directed that the Cabinet Suite (673m(2)) and the main Committee Room (298m(2)) should feature all woollen carpets of 100% Australian origin. These are both prestigious areas of the building, and in the case of the Main Committee Room will be accessible to the public. The Authority has finalised arrangements with Corporate Carpet Installation Services, the contractor for the area concerned, for the provision of 100% Australian woollen carpets in these spaces.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many orders for the payment of child and/or spousal maintenance have been made against liable (a) fathers and (b) mothers by the Child Support Agency (CSA) since it began operating.
(2) What total sum is levied for child and/or spousal maintenance each week by the CSA on liable (a) fathers and (b) mothers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Child Support Registrar advised that from 1 October 1989, the Child Support Agency issues assessments for child support under Stage 2 of the child support legislation. Assessments issue only in the absence of suitable private agreements reached by parties. Spousal maintenance orders remain the province of the courts.
The Agency has issued stage 2 assessments in 65,807 cases to 30 June 1992.
The Agency does not retain information as to the gender of the custodian and a dissection according to the gender of the liable parent cannot be provided.

(2) The Agency generated liabilities for 79,742 cases for May 1992 for payment by 7 June 1992. Total liabilities (including spousal maintenance arising under court orders) generated for the month of June 1992 amounted to $23.5 million. This includes liabilities for both court orders and court registered agreements (Stage 1) and assessments (Stage 2) under the Child Support Scheme.
As the collection system is monthly, the Registrar is unable to readily identify a meaningful weekly amount, as requested in the honourable member's question.
(3) Custody arrangements are not determined by the Agency in either Stage 1 or Stage 2 cases. When contested, custody is determined by the Family Court of Australia under the Family Law Act 1975.
For Stage 1 cases, generally a variation to the court order or ratification of any private agreement must be sought from the courts if custody changes.
Under Stage 2, the Agency may terminate the liability upon notification that a person is no longer an eligible custodian of the child.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ABC buys 50% of the programs it puts to air and either co-produces or produces itself the other 50%.

In determining its internal Budget priorities for 1991-92 the ABC did not have sufficient funds to make Everybody, Holiday or Hypotheticals. Funds however were set aside for the ABC to make The Investigators.

The absence of Everybody and Holiday from the production plan was a disappointment to the ABC and it believed this would prove disappointing to the audience. The ABC therefore pursued methods whereby it could purchase Everybody and Holiday from the independent production industry in 1992-93.

(2) Loredart Pty Ltd, was a company which entered into detailed discussions with the ABC concerning the production of Everybody and Holiday.

(6) Outside packaging of the programs was not put out to tender.
(7) As the Loredart proposal was not proceeded with, the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia did not make a final decision on investment in the Everybody program.

(8) The laws of copyright and 'passing-off', as well as the ABC's contractual rights, form the safe guard to protect the ABC's interests in its own products and the co-productions in which it has broadcast rights and/or an interest in copyright.
There are no legal rights in ideas, titles or formats. The only constraint is if the public is likely to perceive that a similar program is the ABC's program (ie passing-off).

(9) Arrangements with Loredart required ABC Board approval. The ABC Board was made aware of the discussions with Loredart and in the final event, the Board gave approval for the two programs concerned, namely Holiday and Everybody, to be produced by another outside company with the ABC purchasing the program from it.

(10) The Minister has advised that he will not be calling for a report from the ABC Board in regard to Loredart and that he is satisfied that the Board was aware of discussion with Loredart and made decisions appropriate to its role within the Corporation.
