TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: In the interests of promoting equality of educational opportunity will the Government consider allowing the wages of a governess or home tutor employed by farming families in remote areas as a tax deductible expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In general, the fairest way of providing assistance is through the expenditure side of the budget rather than through the taxation system. A tax deduction for the wages of a governess or home tutor would be of most benefit to those most able to afford private tutors and, therefore, may not be the best means of promoting equality of educational opportunity.

The Commonwealth provides direct assistance for remote area education in the form of the Country Areas Program and the Good Schools Strategy. In addition, the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) allowance is provided in recognition of the disadvantages confronted by families in remote areas.
The Government has also broadened the eligibility requirements for various income support measures, including AIC, in response to the problems currently faced by rural communities.
The minimum AIC payment per year has been increased substantially for 1991-92 from $1,500 to $2,500.
Where rural families qualify for Social Security benefits due to hardship provisions, the assets test will no longer apply in assessing eligibility for the maximum AIC allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is comfrey an approved medicinal product; if so, what are its uses; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Comfrey is currently scheduled as a poison and is not approved for any medicinal use.

Comfrey contains significant concentrations of toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are toxic to the liver. The medical literature contains numerous accounts of liver disease and even deaths that are attributable to the consumption of comfrey and comfrey-containing products.

The World Health Organization recently published a major public health review of pyrrolizidine alkaloids as contained in plants such as comfrey, including their use for medicinal purposes. It recommended that sale of such herbs, including comfrey, be restricted.

Notwithstanding, the National Health and Medical Research Council is currently proposing relaxation of the current restrictions on sale of ointments and creams containing comfrey for dermal use because of its assessment that they present little hazard, unlike products for human ingestion.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under existing audit standards is it possible that an audited balance sheet can legally show either a profit or a loss depending on the criteria determined by the directors for treating assets; if so, (a) has this allowed a number of companies to show profits when in fact they are not profitable and (b) are the public thereby denied information necessary to make a proper judgment on investments.
(2) Will he alter the existing audit requirements to ensure that an audited balance sheet reflects the financial situation of an organisation and not just the intentions of the directors.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is:

PARA.TAB: (1) The methodology for determining the quantum of items that have to be disclosed in a company's financial statements and the recommended manner of disclosure are set out in accounting standards which are made by the Australian Accounting Standards Board rather than in auditing standards.

Under the Corporations Law a company's directors are required to prepare financial statements that present a true and fair view of both the profit or loss of the company for the financial year to which the financial statements relate and the state of the company's affairs as at the end of that financial year. When preparing their company's financial statements, directors are required to comply with the requirements of Schedule 5 to the Corporations Regulations and the requirements of all applicable accounting standards.

It is not possible for accounting standards to address every conceivable situation, and the application of an accounting standard in a particular case will often be a matter of judgement. What is important is that mechanisms are in place to ensure that directors are not able to use loose interpretations of standards to provide a misleading impression of the financial position of their company. It is in this area that the Government and its agencies have moved on a number of fronts since the national scheme for corporate regulation commenced operation on 1 January 1991.

First, the Government has brought forward legislation to make the use of accounting standards mandatory. The effect of the amendment is that the financial statements of a company must be prepared in accordance with applicable accounting standards and, where the use of those accounting standards would result in the financial statements not presenting a true and fair view of the matters required to be dealt with in the financial statements, the additional information needed to present a true and fair view must also be disclosed. Prior to this amendment being made, the directors of a company did not have to comply with an applicable accounting standard if, in the directors' opinion, such compliance would result in the financial statements not giving a true and fair view—a situation that, in effect, allowed selective application of accounting standards and thus facilitated the use of misleading "creative accounting".

Secondly, the Australian Accounting Standards Board has set itself a heavy work program involving the revision of older accounting standards and the development and making of new standards in respect of matters that are not currently covered by standards (for example, disclosure of employee benefits and accounting for financial instruments).

An example of a recently revised standard is the standard on valuations, which was strengthened for financial years ending on or after 31 December 1991. It is understood that the commencement of this revised standard, together with the new rules on compulsory application of standards (which also apply to financial years ending on or after 31 December 1991), caused the recent large write-downs by some companies, a development which can only be expected to provide those companies with sounder balance sheets for the future.
Thirdly, there is a need to check that the new rules are being applied. The Australian Securities Commission's compliance program, upon which there is an increasing emphasis, should help ensure this.

(2) As the Australian Accounting Standards Board is an independent body established under section 224 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, it would be improper for me to seek to direct the Board to take a particular course of action in respect of any matter coming within its statutory responsibilities.

There is, however, an ongoing dialogue between the Board and the Attorney-General's Department on policy issues and, since 1 April 1992, a representative of the Department has attended Board meetings as an observer. The presence of the Departmental observer at Board meetings has already proved to be of considerable value to both the Board and the Government in coordinating action on accounting policy, so as to ensure that the accounts of Australian companies acquire an enhanced reputation for completeness and accuracy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Did his Department publish, pursuant to the Marriage Act 1961, a brochure entitled Happily ever before and after which is required to be provided to persons intending to marry in Australia: if so, (a) how many copies were (i) published and (ii) distributed to marriage celebrants and other persons or organisations, (b) has the brochure been withdrawn from circulation; if so, why and (c) what was the cost of publishing and distributing the brochure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Department did publish, in November 1991, pursuant to the Marriage Act 1961, a brochure entitled Happily ever before and after which is required to be provided to persons intending to marry in Australia.

(a) (i) 392,500 copies of the brochure were printed. An equivalent amount was printed of an accompanying brochure, which details where persons may obtain marriage counselling, marriage education and family mediation services from agencies which are approved and funded under the Family Services Program.

(ii) 391,000 copies of each brochure were distributed to the State/Territory Registrars of Births, Deaths and Marriages for distribution to authorised marriage celebrants. Twenty copies of each pamphlet were distributed to all marriage counselling, marriage education and family mediation organisations funded under the Family Services Program. The remainder of the pamphlets were retained within the Department for supplementary distribution as required.

(b) The brochure was withdrawn after it was discovered that the pamphlet contained an incorrect statement of law in some States. The information was corrected and the revised pamphlet was reprinted in February and released in March 1992. As there was no defect with the list of service providers, there was no cause to withdraw this document.

(c) The cost of publishing and distributing the original document and list was $26,379. The cost of replacing and distribution of the 391,000 brochures was $16,355. It must be noted that this document was a new edition and therefore all stocks held by celebrants in Australia were no longer valid and required replacement. In an average year, the Department would print a number of these documents consistent with the Australian Bureau of Statistics data on Marriages registered. The average yearly cost of printing these documents would therefore be around $5,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many women were treated in Australia with human pituitary gonadotrophin (HPG) in each year between 1964 and 1988.
(2) How many of the women referred to in part (1) have died.
(3) How many of the women referred to in part (2) died of Creutzfeldt-Jakob (CJ) disease.

(4) Have any of the women referred to in part (1) been contacted by Commonwealth health authorities and given (a) information and (b) counselling on the connection between HPG and CJ disease; if so, (i) how many women, (ii) when was the contact made, (iii) what information was given and (iv) what counselling was made available.
(5) Has his or his Department's attention been drawn to a report in the Lancet describing a DNA test for susceptibility to CJ disease.

(6) Is a DNA test for susceptibility to CJ disease available in Australia; if not, will arrangements be made for women who may be at risk of contracting CJ disease from HPG treatment to send samples overseas for testing; if not why not.
(7) Will he release the protocols of manufacture used by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for the manufacture of HPG; if not why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Departmental records indicate there were some 1500 women treated under the program. The numbers treated from 1964 to 1985 when the program ceased are listed below. Please note that some women received multiple treatments.
The above figures refer to treatments with Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which is a derivative of HPG.
(2) Not known—this information is not collected by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.
(3) The Department is aware of two cases where women treated under the program have died of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

(4) Commonwealth health authorities have not contacted any of the women direct, but when the program was suspended in 1985 the Department wrote to medical practitioners who participated under the Australian Human Pituitary Hormone Program requesting them to contact and counsel patients about the risk of CJD and of the possibility of secondary transmission. The Department wrote again in November 1990 and again in January and February of this year.
(i) Responses received from participating medical practitioners indicate that as at 26 June 1992, some 352 women have been contacted.
(ii) The date of contact varies between medical practitioners.
(iii) The advice given was that each practitioner should exercise his/her clinical judgement in contacting the person.
(iv) Medical practitioners provided counselling as appropriate according to their clinical judgement in each case.

(5)-(6) Yes. The article described evidence for an hypothesis that susceptibility to CJD is linked to variations in a certain gene and described a technique for testing samples from CJD cases for the variations. The Department is seeking further information on the research to assess its value and to determine if the technique could be carried out in Australia should this prove to be appropriate.

(7) During the period 1969 to 1983 the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) conducted the manufacture of FSH for the Commonwealth program using a method of manufacture devised by CSIRO and approved by the Human Pituitary Advisory Committee. The protocols contain certain know-how which is the intellectual property of CSL and/or third parties. Should the honourable member so wish, arrangements can be made for him to visit CSL and peruse the protocols, but I do not intend that they be made public for reasons of commercial confidentiality.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Are Army surplus rolls of new pure cotton khaki fabric and Army surplus clothing being auctioned at sales in Melbourne; if so, (a) why: (i) has the material become surplus and or (ii) is it being auctioned, (b) will the Army make a profit from the auction, (c) how many other auctions of this kind have occurred since 1990 and (d) what happens to the items not sold at auction.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Government give any guarantees to Australian Airlines in October 1991 in relation to any debt incurred by the company as a result of the deregulation of domestic aviation; if so (a) what guarantees were given, (b) what was the extent of the guarantees and (c) were the losses of fares offered by Australian Airlines at below cost price covered by any guarantees.
(2) Were guarantees given to any other airline.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government did not give any guarantees to Australian Airlines in October 1991 in relation to any debt incurred by the company as a result of the deregulation of domestic aviation.
However the Government has provided an assurance to Australian Airlines in the context of the sales process.

On 13 September 1991 the Government provided Australian Airlines with a letter which could be presented to rating agencies to address any concerns they might have over the airline's credit worthiness arising from uncertainty over the airlines post sale ownership and capital structure.

The Government set a minimum period of 95 days between the date of any trade sale contract to sell majority ownership and the date of final settlement. That was in recognition of concerns that were expressed in relation to the airline's short term commercial paper.

The Government also agreed to undertake, at the time of any contract for majority sale, to take over at settlement date the obligations for any commercial paper issued by the airline after the date of contract that matures after the settlement date. Sale proceeds would be adjusted accordingly.
(2) Guarantees were not given to any other airline.
However the Government has provided an assurance to Qantas in the context of the sales process.

On 11 September 1991 the Government provided Qantas with a letter, that could be presented to lenders, explaining the Government's position in relation to the recapitalisation of Qantas during the sales process. The letter explained that the Government is committed to ensuring that recapitalisation of the airline will occur as a result of the sales process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Army's general reserve (a) largely tasked and trained for the defence of nominated vital assets in the north of mainland Australia and (b) not potentially available for deployment and manoeuvre.

(2) Does the defence plan for Australia provide for the effective strength of little more than one brigade group of regular ground forces to be deployed in immediate defence tasks; if so, in light of the response to part (1), why.

(3) What fully manned trained and equipped regular signals, engineer and armoured elements remain available for urgent defence tasks when the regular Army is depleted by commitments overseas such as those in the Middle East and Cambodia.

(4) What contingency plan exists for dealing with infiltration or concentration of hostile elements directed at any area of Australia south of the Tropic of Capricorn where the greater proportion of Australia's land mass, population and capital infrastructure lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) All of the Army's seven general reserve brigades are potentially available for deployment and manoeuvre. Four of these brigades (4, 9, 11 and 13 Brigades) have also been given the specific training task of preparing for vital asset protection in Northern Australia. The employment of these brigades in any future conflict would be determined by the Government and the Chief of the Defence Force at the time.

(2) Two regular, one Ready Reserve and seven general reserve brigades are currently available for the Defence of Australia. Should a threat to Australia arise the Chief of the Defence Force would task the brigades in the most effective and appropriate way. These ten brigades could be augmented by the raising of additional forces if required.

(3) Defence preparedness is structured to be able to respond to warning. Force Elements are required to mobilise within a stipulated readiness notice to conduct peacetime tasks or operations associated with contingencies credible in the shorter term. Army Force Elements on very short notice are generally able to meet all assigned roles and tasks. Preparedness shortfalls that occur occasionally for these Force Elements are manageable. The specific preparedness of Force Elements is classified information.

(4) Present contingency plans for the defence of Australia address the nature and scope of potential threats in the light of the enduring features of Australia's geo-strategic situation. The Defence of Australia includes all parts of Australia, both south and north of the Tropic of Capricorn. In response to the strategic guidance contained in the 198~ White Paper and subsequent ministerial statements, the Australian Army will progressively move a regular brigade to Darwin between 1993 and 2000. Like the Ready Deployment Force Brigade based in Townsville, the Darwin Brigade will enjoy the advantages of acclimatisation and access to training areas in northern Australia. The majority of Army's combat formations, however, the Ready Reserve brigade and six of the seven General Reserve brigades will remain based south of the Tropic of Capricorn. This balance of regular forces in the north and reserve forces in the south is consistent with strategic guidance and the readiness posture that follows from it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Western Australian Relational Ports: Waterside Workers

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Western Australian Government directed regional port authorities at Esperance, Albany and Geraldton to continue the employment of surplus A register waterside workers.
(2) Does best practice require that the employees referred to in part (1) be employed on a casual basis to accommodate the operations of ports where ships are not regularly loading or unloading.
(3) Has the Minister received representations from the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) concerning its legislated responsibility in the area of the cost of freight and handling.
(4) Have other State Governments taken the action referred to in part (1).
(5) What steps will the Minister take to ensure that the AWB can properly meet its legislated obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am informed that the Western Australian Government has not given directions to regional ports in that State concerning new labour arrangements being introduced under the waterfront reform process. Further, I am informed that the labour requirements at the ports of Esperance, Albany and Geraldton will be based solely on operational needs. In those circumstances, there should be no idle time and no surplus employees under the new arrangements.
(2) See (1) above.

(3) No. The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has not written to myself or the former Minister for Shipping and Aviation specifically drawing attention to its legislated responsibilities in the area of the cost of freight and handling. I am advised, however, that the AWB has written on a number of occasions to my predecessor on a range of matters which could be regarded as broadly consistent with the general object of furthering its legislated responsibility for minimising costs for storage, handling and carriage of wheat and the provision of port services in connection with the carriage of wheat.
(4) I am not aware of any State Governments directing regional port authorities to continue the employment of surplus 'A Register' waterside workers.

(5) As indicated in the answer to (3) above, I am unaware of any statement by the AWB that it is not in a position to "properly meet its legislated obligations" by actions which fall within my portfolio responsibilities.
The AWB, and through it the Australian wheat industry, have been major beneficiaries of improved efficiency and cost savings under the Government's waterfront reform program.

Revised bulk grain terminal manning arrangements based on real operating requirements, providing labour reductions of between 50 and 80 per cent, have been implemented under the waterfront In-Principle Agreement in all bulk grain loading ports.

In a press statement released on 4 November 1991, the AWB indicated that Australian ports are now among the most efficient grain loading ports in the world. The AWB has also indicated that the total savings to the grains industry resulting from waterfront reforms could be in the order of $10 million per annum. This saving has been achieved through a 50 per cent reduction in the cost of stevedoring in bulk grain terminals and a significant reduction in grain ship turnaround times since 1988-89 from 4.52 days to 2.4 days.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has the Commonwealth Government done in feral animal control since 1983.
(2) What feral animal control programs, in particular in connection with rabbits, have been funded through the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Constitutionally, major responsibility for control of feral animals lies with the state and territory governments. Under their legislation, the landholder/occupier, whether government or non-government, is required to control declared feral animals.

The Commonwealth has and continues to have a major input into feral animal research including development of control techniques. My colleague, the honourable Senator Cook, recently detailed Commonwealth expenditure on rabbit research in an answer to a question on notice from Senator Lees.

Concerning feral animal control, the Commonwealth's primary input is through its responsibility for the land it manages, national parks, Commonwealth acquired land and external territories. Some feral animals have also been controlled as part of the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign (BTEC), as demonstration projects funded under the Decade of Landcare initiative, under the past Community Employment Program and the current Aboriginal Employment Development Policy and the Contract Employment Program for Aboriginals in Natural and Cultural Resource Management.
The following is a summary of information on Commonwealth input into feral animal control since 1983 (Rabbit control projects are denoted by an *):
Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS)

ANPWS is responsible for managing Kakadu, Uluru, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island National Parks, and parts of some external territories. As part of the ANPWS wildlife management strategy, feral animal control is carried out in all parks. It also provides extensive funds for research into major pests of Australia's endangered native plants and animals through the Endangered Species Program.
Kakadu National Park
Approximately 80,000 buffalo and feral cattle have been removed since 1983, primarily for conservation but also as part of BTEC. There are now less than 1000 buffalo in the Park.
There are localised infestations of feral pigs. Control is limited to areas of high public use and where there is easy access.
*There has been an extensive rabbit control program since 1986. A pilot bounty system for control of feral cats has recently been introduced.
Christmas Island
Introduced wolf snakes, cats and dogs are controlled on the island.
Norfolk Island
Crimson rosellas (which are not native to Norfolk Island) and cats and rats are continuously controlled in high priority areas, such as the breeding areas of the endangered Green Parrot.
*With the assistance of Norfolk Island residents, rabbits were eradicated from Phillip Island in the Territory of Norfolk Island during the period 1979-1986.
Other areas
Rats were eradicated from West Island in Ashmore Reef National Nature Reserve. A similar program is underway in the Coringa-Herald National Nature Reserve.
Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign (BTEC)
BTEC has operated since 1970 and aims to eradicate tuberculosis and brucellosis from stock. Feral buffalo and uncontrolled cattle have been removed under the program.
Community Employment Program (CEP) and the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy (AEDP)
A number of feral animal control programs were funded in 1986 under CEP. These included:
maintenance of the dingo barrier fence near Charleville with the Queensland Rural Lands Protection Board,
*rabbit-control in the southern central Northern Territory,
maintenance of wild dog fencing in Kosciusko National Park.
Since 1988 the following feral animal control has been funded under AEDP.
*soil conservation including rabbit-control in the Lake Albert Catchment near Wagga Wagga,
*pest animal (primarily rabbit) and pest plant control on the foreshores of Glenbawn Dam, NSW, and at Noonkanbah Station, Western Australia,
feral pig control on Sir Graeme Moore Island, Western Australia,
training of aboriginal pest animal and weed control officers in Moulamein and Dubbo, NSW.
Contract Employment Program for Aboriginals in National and Cultural Resource Management

Feral animal control projects funded under this program since 1988 include; feral pig control in the Cadell River area of Arnhem Land, feral horse control, Hermannsburg, Northern Territory and the following rabbit control programs:
* Western Australia—Brookton, Gibson Desert and Narrogin regions.
* South Australia—Murraylands, and Port Lincoln National Parks.
* Victoria—Aboriginal burial sites, Mildura.
National Soil Conservation Program
*Demonstration projects on rabbit control have been funded since the program commenced in 1989 in the following localities:
NSW—Ivanhoe Rangecare Group;
Victoria—North Harcourt-Sedgwick, Sutton Grange, Amphitheatre, Kingoonya and Yaapeet groups;
South Australia—South Australian Department of Agriculture;
Northern Territory—Central Australian Management Association.
Department of Defence

The Department of Defence controls 3.8 million hectares of land with range of feral animals including pigs, rabbits, buffalo, donkeys, goats and horses. Their control is undertaken consistent with relevant state, territory or local government legislation.

On a more general level, $480,000 over four years (1990/91-1993/94) has been allocated to the Bureau of Rural Resources within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to develop national strategies for the coordinated management of both the environmental and economic impact of major pests including rabbits. A draft feral horse strategy is soon to be circulated for comment while a draft rabbit strategy, which will identify major information deficiencies and establish priorities for research, is expected to be circulated later in 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the chronology of events associated with the consideration of an independent FM licence and supplementary licences at (a) Albury, NSW, and (b) Lismore, NSW, since 1984.
(2) Has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal reversed its initial assessment of the commercial viability of FM licences at (a) Albury and (b) Lismore in recent months.
(3) Have supplementary licence applications been lodged by local AM operators in (a) Albury and (b) Lismore; if so, were the applications lodged within the correct time frame.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The chronology of events associated with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's Albury and Lismore licence grant inquiries is:
(a) Albury
20 September 1984—A supplementary FM licence application was received from Malcorp Pty Ltd, the then licensee company for 2AY Albury;

23 August 1989—Minister Willis dismissed 2AY's supplementary licence application. The Minister made a prima facie finding that the Albury market could support an additional commercial FM radio service;

14 February 1990—Minister Willis called applications for an independent licence and published a service area and draft technical conditions for the Albury market. One independent applicant, Albury-Wodonga Broadcasters Pty Ltd, responded. Submissions were also received from Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd, which is the licensee company for 2AY and is a subsidiary company of Wesgo Communications Pty Ltd, and North East Broadcasters Pty Ltd, licensee of 3NE, whose service area partly overlaps that of 2AY;
2 May 1990—The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) commenced its inquiry into the grant of a new commercial FM radio licence to serve Albury;

3 January 1992—Amendments to the Broadcasting Act came into effect which oblige the ABT to prefer independent applications to supplementary licence applications, when considering both simultaneously, and which limit the ABT's consideration of the commercial viability of incumbent licensees to the period up to the expiration of that licence;
5 February 1992—The ABT convened a conference of parties to examine the impact of the changed provision relating to commercial viability as it affects 2AY and 3NE;

31 March 1992—Wesgo Communications Pty Ltd lodged a supplementary licence application on behalf of Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd with the Department of Transport and Communications. On 8 April 1992 Departmental advice recommending that Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd's supplementary licence application should be referred to the ABT was forwarded to the Minister for Transport and Communications;
6-7 April—The ABT held its licence grant Inquiry hearings in Albury. The hearings remains part-heard and are scheduled to recommence on 22 June 1992;
14 May 1992—Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd's supplementary licence application was lodged with the ABT;

21 May 1992—The ABT commenced an Inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence for Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd which is being conducted simultaneously with the Inquiry into the grant of a new licence for Albury. The closing date for submissions is 15 July, 1992.
(b) Lismore
18 September 1984—The Department of Transport and Communications received a supplementary licence application from Richmond River Broadcasters Pty Ltd, the licensee company for 2LM Lismore;

13 April 1988—Minister Evans found a prima facie case that the Lismore market could support a new independent commercial FM radio service and dismissed Richmond River Broadcasters' supplementary licence application;
8 May 1988—Minister Evans called for applications for an independent FM licence to serve Lismore and published a draft service area and technical conditions;
28 July 1988—The ABT commenced its Inquiry into the grant of a new commercial radio licence to serve Lismore;
18 December 1989—ABT published the report on its decision to grant a licence to Northern NSW FM Pty Ltd. This decision was appealed by Richmond River Broadcasters and Northern Rivers FM Pty Ltd;

12 February 1990—Justice Morling in the Federal Court ordered that the ABT's decision be set aside and remitted back to the Tribunal on the grounds that natural justice was denied to the parties by the ABT's failure to make available to them a report detailing the financial performance of a group of comparative services before this analysis was published in the report on the ABT's decision in December 1989;
12 July 1990—Justice Einfield in the Federal Court ordered that Mr Bruce Allen not sit as the Division for the reconstituted authority;

24 January 1991—Following an unsuccessful appeal by Northern NSW FM Pty Ltd against Justice Einfield's decision, Mr Tim O'Keefe was appointed to sit as the ABT's Division for its reconstituted Lismore Inquiry;

17 December 1991—The ABT published a preliminary view that neither the commercial viability of 2LM nor that of the adjacent service provided by 2MW Murwillumbah would be prejudiced by the grant of a new commercial radio licence to serve Lismore;

20 February 1992—The Minister for Transport and Communications wrote to the Chairman of the ABT seeking his views on the practicability of joining an inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence for Richmond River Broadcasters with its Inquiry into the grant of a new commercial radio licence to serve Lismore;

21 February 1992—The Chairman of the ABT wrote to the Minister stating that he saw no impediment to the referral of a supplementary licence application from Richmond River Broadcasters. The Chairman also stated that, although any decision to join a supplementary licence Inquiry with the current Lismore Inquiry rested with the Lismore Division, the ABT "has in the past chosen to join commercial grant inquiries with related supplementary licence inquiries";

6 March 1992—The Minister wrote to the Chairman of the ABT advising him that Richmond River Broadcasters had indicated that a supplementary licence application would be lodged with the Minister in the near future;
9-10 March 1992—The ABT held hearings in Lismore. Richmond River Broadcasters indicated during that hearing that they would be in a position to lodge a supplementary licence application by 1 April;
31 March 1992—Richmond River Broadcasters Pty Ltd lodged a supplementary licence application with the Department of Transport and Communications;

8 April 1992—Departmental advice recommending that Richmond River Broadcasters Pty Ltd's supplementary licence application should be referred to the ABT was forwarded to the Minister for Transport and Communications;
12 May 1992—The Minister referred Richmond River Broadcasters' supplementary licence application to the ABT;
13 May 1992—The ABT announced its decision not to grant a new independent radio licence to serve Lismore;
22 May 1992—The ABT commenced an Inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence to Richmond River Broadcasters.

(2) (a) and (b) During the Lismore Inquiry, the ABT was obliged under Section 80B of the Broadcasting Act to consider the effect on the commercial viability of an existing licence of granting an additional licence, but only for the period up to the incumbent licence's expiration. (On the 18th of June 1992, the Senate passed the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which included an amendment to Section 80B requiring the ABT to consider the commercial viability of an incumbent licence for a period of 5 years from the date of its decision to grant a new licence).

Under Section 83A of the Act, the ABT is obliged to refuse to grant a licence to a person if the Tribunal is not satisfied that the person has the financial and management capacities necessary to provide an adequate and comprehensive service pursuant to the licence.

The ABT's preliminary view of the commercial viability of 2LM Lismore and 2MW Murwillumbah, published in December 1991, concluded that neither service would be prejudiced by the grant of a new licence to serve Lismore. The ABT's decision not to grant a new licence in Lismore was based on its analysis of more recent financial data from the 1990-91 Financial Year, which showed a continuing decline in the revenue generated in the Lismore radio market; the ABT's projections of an irreversible loss of revenue from radio to television following the commencement of Television Equalisation in northern NSW and the projected increases in 2LM's expenditure in response to Equalisation; and 2LM's reduced capacity to further cut staffing costs.
The ABT did not base its decision not to grant a new licence on Section 83A of the Act.

The ABT has not published any preliminary view of the commercial viability of 2AY given the introduction of a new competitive service, and, as it has not yet concluded the Albury Inquiry, has not made any determination under Section 83A in relation to this Inquiry.

(3) (a) and (b) As indicated in the chronology of the Albury and Lismore inquiries, both 2AY Albury and 2LM Lismore have lodged supplementary licence applications, and these have been referred to the ABT for its consideration.

Section 82A of the Broadcasting Act, which provides for supplementary licence applications, does not set any limitations on the times at which incumbent licensees may submit supplementary licence applications.

Richmond River Broadcasters Pty Ltd indicated to the ABT at the Lismore hearing on 9-10 March that they would endeavour to lodge a supplementary licence application with the Department of Transport and Communications before 1 April. Richmond River Broadcasters' supplementary licence application was lodged on 31 March.

As noted in my answer to question 1, the ABT can, and has in the past, joined supplementary licence and new commercial licence grant inquiries. However, Richmond River Broadcasters' referred application was not received by the ABT until after the Lismore new licence grant Inquiry was concluded. The ABT has therefore commenced a separate Inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence to Richmond River Broadcasters.

The ABT's Inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence to Radio Albury-Wodonga Pty Ltd is being conducted simultaneously with its continuing Inquiry into the grant of a new commercial radio licence in Albury.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following the report on proposed radiology regulations by the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, will the Government investigate further options to restructure Medicare payments for radiology services; if so, when will the investigation be complete.

(2) Has the Government considered an item by item evaluation of the Medicare schedule items relating to the provision of radiology services taking into account the costs and skill involved in the delivery of each service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to complaints that bureaucratic red tape is preventing the development of value-added meat exports.

(2) Is it a fact that the health certificate cannot be prepared until the "intention to export" form is signed and the truck of meat sealed by an Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) inspector at the meat plant; if so, must the health certificate be prepared after the truck has already left to go to the airport and has the export company then to drive to an AQIS office in the town to get the health certificate completed and then deliver it to the airfreight agent in time for the meat to be shipped.

(3) Is it also a fact that if there is a simple typing error the health certificate is rejected and must be retyped; if so, will he have the procedures changed and the practice adopted of allowing both parties to initial the error.
(4) Does unnecessary bureaucracy force companies to look at establishing businesses offshore.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I do not accept that bureaucratic red tape is preventing the development of value added meat exports. There are very specific requirements that have to be met by exporters of meat and meat products. These requirements are imposed by overseas countries and are often more stringent than those operating within Australia. AQIS is responsible for ensuring that they are met.

(2) The preparation of the health certificate can be commenced at any time but, by necessity, it cannot be completed until all details of the consignment are known eg container numbers and seal numbers.

The exporter must deliver the completed health certificate to an AQIS regional office for checking of format and importing country requirements and endorsements before the certificate is signed and sealed. These offices are located in close proximity to the majority of meat exporters.

The health certificate can only be issued on sighting the pink copy of the "export permit" which contains all the details. The exporter is then responsible for delivering the signed health certificate to his forwarding agent.
AQIS regional offices have and are willing to make arrangements for out of hours issuing for special airfreights.

(3) Australian Meat Health Certificates are government to government documents that have been negotiated with importing country authorities. It is a long standing policy that is internationally recognised and accepted that such certificates are not issued with corrections. To do so could bring into question the standing of the Australian certification system.

A system of initialling minor corrections would not be acceptable to the majority of Australia's meat trading partners. The main reason for this is that there are problems associated with the recognition of initials and overseas authorities have no way of knowing whether the correction was done in Australia by AQIS or elsewhere. Any wrongful alteration could place the whole of Australia's export meat trade to that destination at risk.

In some cases the error is not detected until it has reached its destination and it is the overseas authorities who reject the certificate and insist on a replacement. Where errors are detected more stringent import examinations are often imposed on Australian meat.
Under the circumstances I could not agree to changing the existing procedures.

(4) I am not aware of any such instances in the meat industry. However if the honourable member has evidence to the contrary I would welcome his passing that information on to me and I will certainly look into the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 4 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What does the Government propose for the Cocos Islands animal quarantine station.
(2) What cost recovery percentage is required for the quarantine station to remain viable.
(3) Is this level of cost recovery being achieved; if not, what is the level of cost recovery.
(4) Does the cost recovery policy include the cost of maintaining the Perth office; if so, what is the cost of the Perth office.
(5) Is the Perth office a necessary element of the Cocos Island facility; if so, why.
(6) What action has been taken to increase the operating efficiency of the station.
(7) Has action taken included (a) a longer rotation of officers, (b) multi-skilling and (c) greater use of local staff.
(8) What percentage of the annual maximum capacity of the station (a) was used in 1991-1992 and is estimated to be used in (b) 1991-92 and (c) 1992-93.
(9) What species of animal are anticipated to be the major users of the station over the next five years.
(10) What are the criteria for the use of the station over one of the mainland quarantine facilities in relation to (a) diseases and (b) animals' countries of origin.
(11) What restrictions are placed on the use of the station by overseas principals for the transfer of animals to (a) Australia and (b) other countries.

(12) What action is being taken to increase the usage of the station, including by (a) marketing the facility internationally and (b) offering time slot or other packages for the total station to private sector contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government proposes to maintain the presence of a high security quarantine on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands for the immediate future to enable Australian importers to gain access to genetic material from high risk countries. The longer term future of the station may well be influenced by developments in fields such as embryo technology where developments may well lead to the ability to implant with a high level of safety on the mainland.

(2) Under the policy for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to be fully cost recoverable, desirably the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Animal Quarantine Station (CIAQS) should recover 100% of costs. In practice this is unlikely due to quarantine problems of maintaining continuity of usage of CIAQS for imports from high risk countries. No specific recovery % has been determined in terms of CIAQS' viability.
(3) The level of 100% cost recovery is not being achieved. The level of cost recovery for 1991-1992 is estimated to be $358,300 or 40%.

(4) The cost base for CIAQS includes a proportion of the costs of running the Perth office based on the proportion of services undertaken by the Perth office on behalf of CIAQS. It also includes the cost of the Perth office services for barrier operations (quarantine clearance of planes and boats). This latter cost has been removed from the 92/93 cost base.
The cost of the Perth office is $63,193 being the salary and administrative costs to support the animal quarantine operations at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

(5) The Perth office is a necessary element of CIAQS under the current regionalised management system. The Perth office handles personnel and financial matters for CIAQS and provides a general administrative oversight.
(6) The major operating efficiencies that have been undertaken are:
(a) the removal of sentinel animals during periods when no quarantine program is in progress;

(b) a reduction in staff numbers from eleven (9 x AQIS officers and 2 x Cocos Malays) to six (4 x AQIS officers and 2 x Cocos Malays). This will be further reduced to five (3 x AQIS officers and 2 x Cocos Malays) in July 1992;
(c) a requirement for importers to provide additional labour during periods when a quarantine program is in progress; and
(d) a move to have a veterinary officer stationed at CIAQS only during the period of a quarantine program.
(7) (a) Action has been taken to extend the rotation of some officers.
(b) Officers have been trained to undertake multi-skilling in regard to quarantine station duties and barrier control duties.
(c) Limited use has been made of local personnel and this is an additional option that may be considered to reduce costs if and when suitable local personnel are available.
(8) CIAQS operates on single quarantines on an all-in, all-out basis and revenue is based on a monthly or part there-of charge regardless of the size of the consignment.
(a) During 1991-92 the percentage usage of the annual maximum capacity was 41.6%.
(b) Based on approved priorities, the usage of CIAQS for 1991-92 was estimated to be in the order of 70%.
(c) 50% excluding cleaning and disinfection down time and slippage which is a normal part of importations from high risk countries.
(9) The species of animals likely to use CIAQS over the next five years are:
zoo animals from high risk countries
camelids from high risk countries
ostriches from high risk and low to medium risk countries
zoo avian species
bovine embryos from high risk countries.

(10) (a) CIAQS is used in lieu of mainland quarantine stations when importations present an increased risk of introduction of major animal diseases and pests such as foot and mouth disease, Rift Valley fever and major avian diseases eg. Newcastle disease. It is particularly important for eliminating the risks associated with vector borne diseases.
(b) CIAQS is used for importations from high risk countries. High risk countries are those where major animals diseases and pests of concern to Australia are present.

(11) (a) No restrictions have been placed on overseas principals to use CIAQS for transfer of animals into Australia. Overseas principals would only be given a lower priority for use if their applications are of equal merit with Australian applicants.
The New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries has been advised that applications for use of CIAQS from that country would be considered along with applications from Australia.

(b) AQIS has not sought applications from other countries for use of CIAQS nor has AQIS received any formal applications from countries other than New Zealand. AQIS has however, received one enquiry for possible use of the facility by an overseas country other than New Zealand.

(12) AQIS has sought to increase the usage of the station by seeking to have the Animal Import Priorities Committee which consists of government and industry representatives and, which allocates priorities for use of CIAQS, to approve multiple usage for approved importers if required. The Committee has supported this approach on the one occasion it was requested.
(a) CIAQS has not been marketed internationally although it may be a possible avenue for increasing its usage and as such will be given further consideration.

(b) Time slot or other packages have not been offered to private sector contractors but this is an option that could be considered for the future and the legality of such a proposal will be investigated. There are other aspects of such a proposal that would require investigation to ensure access can be assured for all genuine applicants.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are there more than 104 states party to the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
(2) Has any one state other than Australia made declarations or reservations with respect to Article 4(a) of the Convention; if so, what is the text of the reservation or declaration in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Currently there are 132 states parties to the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination.
(2) The following states parties have made declarations or reservations with respect to Article 4(a) of the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination:
Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, Austria, Bahamas, Barbados, Belgium, Fiji, France, Italy, Malta, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, Tonga, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
The texts of each reservation or declaration in each case is as follows:

The Government of Antigua and Barbuda interprets article 4 of the Convention as requiring a Party to enact measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only where it is considered that the need arises to enact such legislation.

The Government of Australia...declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by article 4(a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, public mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of article 4(a).

Article 4 of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination provides that the measures specifically described in sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) shall be undertaken with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5 of the Convention. The Republic of Austria therefore considers that through such measures the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association may not be jeopardized. These rights are laid down in articles 19 and 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights; they were reaffirmed by the General Assembly of the United Nations when it adopted articles 19 and 21 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and are referred to in article 5 (d)(viii) and (ix) of the present Convention.

Firstly, the Government of the Commonwealth of the Bahamas wishes to state its understanding of article 4 of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. It interprets article 4 as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only in so far as it may consider with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration set out in article 5 of the Convention (in particular to freedom of opinion and expression and the right of freedom of peaceful assembly and association) that some legislative addition to, or variation of existing law and practice in these fields is necessary for the attainment of the ends specified in article 4. Lastly, the Constitution of the Commonwealth of the Bahamas entrenches and guarantees to every person in the Commonwealth of the Bahamas the fundamental rights and freedoms of the individual irrespective of his race or place of origin. The Constitution prescribes judicial process to be observed in the event of the violation of any of these rights whether by the State or by a private individual. Acceptance of this Convention by the Commonwealth of the Bahamas does not imply the acceptance of obligations going beyond the constitutional limits nor the acceptance of any obligations to introduce judicial process beyond these prescribed under the Constitution.

The Constitution of Barbados entrenches and guarantees to every person in Barbados the fundamental rights and freedoms of the individual irrespective of his race or place of origin. The Constitution prescribes judicial processes to be observed in the event of the violation of any of these rights whether by the State or by a private individual. Accession to the Convention does not imply the acceptance of obligations going beyond the constitutional limits nor the acceptance of any obligations to introduce judicial processes beyond those provided in the Constitution.

The Government of Barbados interprets article 4 of the said Convention as requiring a Party to the Convention to enact measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only where it is considered that the need arises to enact such legislation.

In order to meet the requirements or article 4 of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, the Kingdom of Belgium will take care to adapt its legislation to the obligations it has assumed in becoming a party to the said Convention.

The Kingdom of Belgium nevertheless wishes to emphasize the importance which it attaches to the fact that article 4 of the Convention provides that the measures laid down in sub-paragraphs (a), (b), and (c) should be adopted with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5 of the Convention. The Kingdom of Belgium therefore considers that the obligations imposed by article 4 must be reconciled with the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to peaceful assembly and association. Those rights are proclaimed in articles 19 and 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and have been reaffirmed in articles 19 and 21 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. They have also been stated in article 5, sub-paragraph (d)(viii) and (ix) of the said Convention.

The Government of Fiji wishes to state its understanding of certain articles in the Convention. It interprets article 4 as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only in so far as it may consider with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5 of the Convention (in particular the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association) that some legislative addition to or variation of existing law and practice in those fields is necessary for the attainment of the end specified in the earlier part of article 4.

With regard to article 4, France wishes to make it clear that it interprets the reference made therein to the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and to the rights set forth in article 5 of the Convention as releasing the States Parties from the obligation to enact anti-discrimination legislation which is incompatible with the freedoms of opinion and expression and of peaceful assembly and association guaranteed by those texts.

ANSWER.PARA: Declaration made upon signature and confirmed upon ratification

PARA.TAB: The positive measures, provided for in article 4 of the Convention and specifically described in sub-paragraphs (a) and (b) of that article, designed to eradicate all incitement to, or acts of, discrimination, are to be interpreted, as that article provides, "with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5" of the Convention. Consequently, the obligations deriving from the aforementioned article 4 are not to jeopardize the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association which are laid down in articles 19 and 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, were reaffirmed by the General Assembly of the United Nations when it adopted articles 19 and 21 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and are referred to in articles 5(d)(viii) and (ix) of the Convention. In fact, the Italian Government, in conformity with the obligations resulting from Articles 55(c) and 56 of the Charter of the United Nations, remains faithful to the principle laid down in article 29(2) of the Universal Declaration, which provides that "in the exercise of his rights and freedoms, everyone shall be subject only to such limitations as are determined by law solely for the purpose of securing due recognition and respect for the rights and freedoms of others and of meeting the just requirements of morality, public order and the general welfare in a democratic society."

ANSWER.PARA: Declaration made upon signature and confirmed upon ratification:

PARA.TAB: The Government of Malta wishes to state its understanding of certain articles in the Convention.

It interprets article 4 as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article should it consider, with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights set forth in article 5 of the Convention, that the need arises to enact `ad hoc' legislation, in addition to or variation of existing law and practice to bring to an end any act of racial discrimination.

The Constitution of Nepal contains provisions for the Protection of individual rights, including the right to freedom of speech and expression, the right to form unions and associations not motivated by party politics and the right to freedom of professing his/her own religion; and nothing in the Convention shall be deemed to require or to authorize legislation or other action by Nepal incompatible with the provisions of the Constitution of Nepal.

His Majesty's Government interprets article 4 of the said Convention as requiring a Party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only insofar as His Majesty's Government may consider, with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, that some legislative addition to, or variation of, existing law and practice in those fields is necessary for the attainment of the end specified in the earlier part of article 4. His Majesty's Government interprets the requirement in article 6 concerning `reparation or satisfaction' as being fulfilled if one or other of these forms of redress is made available; and further interprets `satisfaction' as including any form of redress effective to bring the discriminatory conduct to an end.

The Government of Papua New Guinea interprets article 4 of the Convention as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the areas covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only in so far as it may consider with due regard to the principles contained in the Universal Declaration set out in Article 5 of the Convention that some legislative addition to, or variation of existing law and practice, is necessary to give effect to the provisions of Article 4. In addition, the Constitution of Papua New Guinea guarantees certain fundamental rights and freedoms to all persons irrespective of their race or place of origin. The Constitution also provides for judicial protection of these rights and freedoms. Acceptance of this Convention does not therefore indicate the acceptance of obligations by the Government of Papua New Guinea which go beyond those provided by the Constitution, nor does it indicate the acceptance of any obligation to introduce judicial process beyond that provided by the Constitution. (The reservation was circulated by the Secretary-General on 22 February 1982.)

The Kingdom of Tonga wishes to state its understanding of certain articles in the Convention. It interprets article 4 as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only in so far as it may consider with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5 of the Convention (in particular the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association) that some legislative addition to or variation of existing law and practice in those fields is necessary for the attainment of the end specified in the earlier part of article 4.

ANSWER.PARA: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

PARA.TAB: Subject to the following reservation and interpretative statements:

The United Kingdom wishes to state its understanding of certain articles in the Convention. It interprets article 4 as requiring a party to the Convention to adopt further legislative measures in the fields covered by sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of that article only in so far as it may consider with due regard to the principles embodied in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the rights expressly set forth in article 5 of the Convention (in particular the right to freedom of opinion and expression and the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association) that some legislative addition to or variation of existing law and practice in those fields is necessary for the attainment of the end specified in the earlier part of article 4.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

(2) Has Mr Ian Spicer and other employers' representatives led major campaigns on the issue referred to in part (1); if so, is the Minister able to say if the represented employers cannot afford to pay increased wages or superannuation.
(3) Did the employers referred to in part (2) increase their own incomes by an average of 300 per cent more than that experienced by wage earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

The introduction of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge (SGC) must be viewed in the context of a prolonged period of wage restraint on the part of wage and salary earners. The SGC will be more than funded by the substantial improvements in productivity which are anticipated to flow from the progression of workplace and labour market reform initiatives and the Government's other structural reforms. In fact, expected productivity gains during the scheduled period cover aggregate contributions several times over. As noted in the Treasurer's press release of 16 May 1992, the impact of the SGC will also be taken into account in any national wage rise in 1992-93, so that it will in no way jeopardise the Accord commitment to achieving wage outcomes which are consistent with maintaining an inflation rate which is comparable with those of our major trading partners.

(3) The discipline shown by wage and salary earners is in stark contrast to the excessive increases in executive remuneration during the same period. A recent survey by Noble Lowndes Cullen Egan Dell reveals that total remuneration for managers increased by an average of 5.3 per cent over the year to March 1992. The corresponding figure for senior managers is 7.1 per cent. In comparison, average weekly earnings for wage and salary earners increased by just 2.2 per cent over the year to February 1992. The continued failure of executives to demonstrate restraint similar to that shown by wage and salary earners could have serious implications for the stability of the wages system as the economy moves more strongly into recovery.

(4) Details of Mr Ian Spicer's superannuation scheme are not contained in the Confederation of Australian Industry's 1990-91 Annual Report, so it is only possible to speculate as to the source and magnitude of any such contributions, and whether or not employers can afford them.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 994 (Hansard, 8 October 1991, page 1491), what progress has been made in persuading the USA to support the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As stated in the answer to question No. 994 (Hansard, 8 October 1991, page 1491), Australia has been in direct and regular contact with the United States Government on law of the sea issues since 1981 when the House of Representatives conveyed its unanimous resolution on the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea to the United States Government. That contact has continued since the last time a question was asked on this topic in August 1991.

In particular, Australia, the United States and other countries have been participating in consultations chaired by the UN Secretary-General to explore the concerns which certain countries, particularly the United States, have with the deep seabed mining provisions embodied in Part XI of the Law of the Sea Convention.

Recently consultations were held in October 1991, December 1991 and June 1992. During the course of these consultations it was acknowledged by all participants, whether from industrialised or developing countries, that global political and economic changes since the adoption of the Law of the Sea Convention in 1982 had raised questions as to the appropriateness of certain aspects of Part XI. This view was embodied in last year's United Nations General Assembly resolution 46/78 on the Law of the Sea. A milestone was achieved in December 1991 when, for the first time, the United

ANSWER.PARA: States moved from a negative vote to an abstention on this annual resolution. Australia played an active role in the consultations which led to this result.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government considers that it will be possible to reach an accommodation on Part XI which would enable the United States and others to accede to or ratify the Law of the Sea Convention. This would allow universal participation in the creation of a uniform and binding international legal order for the oceans.
